I don't know which is more prominent at this point, lasagna or canned pineapples but I definitely know one thing - 91 Days /is/ worth the watch.
To say that 91 Days is like any other series that attempts to exploit the theme of "vengeance" is a slight understatement. Truly, the series works on Angelo's plans of "an eye for an eye". But it doesn't simply exploit how vengeance works in the mafia world, or how vengeance can drive you to be a cold-hearted bastard and ruin people's lives. Rather, it presents the question if revenge is really worth fighting for and that at the endof the day, will you truly find the happiness you believe you lost because of those who took it away from you? Would it not be better to live in the present and appreciate what is around you? It isn't that philosophical so fret not, it won't be a boring ride. The story achieves that by incorporating the theme of revenge into the main story where mafia groups attempt to overpower each other.


It is clear to say that 91 Days has solid, consistent writing with the appropriate tone. They don't shove bullshit into your face (yes it will lose some of its pacing along the way) because by the time you finish the whole series, you will understand how they are inter-related and work to exemplify the significant of relationship formed between the main characters, Angelo and Nero. Even canned pineapples are significant. 


And if you can actually predict each episode, really, I couldn't. 91 Days basically gives you the expectation of what may happen in the upcoming episode but always works to overrule every single expectation you have. 


Even so, 91 Days fails at the quality of its art. The animation lacks fluidity. It doesn't give viewers scenic views but instead a backdrop of lackluster colours, and lifeless buildings and objects. Then again, this does help to provide a serious, mature tone to the setting. If you have already watched the series, you may find that certain scenes have more vibrant colours in order to lighten the atmosphere and bring out the light interactions between the characters. Well, at least you make up for those sad backgrounds. 


The characters are rather unmemorable. Especially when they look almost the same with the same hair colour. Those who particularly struck out (hair colour, hair styles) were of more importance (well, that's honestly nothing new). It fascinates me that there was no access into any of these characters minds, in a way dehumanizing them. Not that its a new thing but it really works when the camera techniques are nuance in its attempts of capturing the character's emotions, Avilio in particular who is the hardest character to actually read. The usage of certain close-ups, or even wide shots of Avilio made me wonder what Avilio is thinking at that moment, what is he planning, or is he genuine? Because of this, I struggle with my own opinions of certain characters because they would be subtly antagonized throughout the story. Without a reason behind their actions, unless stated, I was momentarily lost between who was right and wrong. 


All in all, 91 Days is that one series you don't want to miss. If you've dropped it because you were put off by the slow pacing during Episode 4 and 5 or the art, give it another try until Episode 6 and see if you still enjoy it. It's not going to be everyone's cup of tea though. I mean, you won't enjoy lasagna that much after watching that one particular episode.

EDITED FOR GRAMMER
Ah it’s been a while since we've got an anime that veered away from the usual cliches and tropes that could be found in nearly every single show nowadays. I'm talking about the moeblob characters, the endless amount of exposition, girls getting their clothes ripped to shreds for the purpose of fanservice, spiky haired characters screaming their lungs out at their opponents and so on. Therefore it’s refreshing to see a show that stays far away from many of these cliches and tries to gather inspiration from another medium instead: western gangster films. 
A 1900s setting, mafia members, tommy guns, the prohibition, boozeand lots of people getting turned into swiss cheese by bullets. This ladies and gentlemen is what 91 Days aspires to become. A show that takes many of its influences from gangster flicks such as The Godfather and Goodfellas. And it shows. There is a lot of emphasis on “show don’t tell” which is a great storytelling choice that is highly lacking in modern anime to this day. Lots of things are presented to us rather than told through pointless exposition sequences and certain clues are left to the audience to figure out rather than just handed to us on a silver platter straight away. It’s a show that respects the mature audience it’s catering towards which is something I really appreciate.


The overall story is that of a typical revenge thriller. Some bloke called Angelo Lagusa witnesses his family being murdered by a collection of Mafia members and flees the scene of the crime to safety. Years later, he emerges under a new name: Avilio Bruno. His only goal: to obliterate the very men who were responsible for the death of his family and his one lead is a letter that points to the Vanetti Family as the perpetrators of the crime. This tale follows Avilio as he tries to get involved with the Vanettis in an attempt to stealthily pick his opponents off one by one.


As a revenge thriller, 91 Days pulls no punches. Don’t get attached to any character in this series because it will wreck you emotionally in the end. A lot of characters die in this series as part of Avilio’s revenge plan. Nearly nobody is spared. Blood will be split and the show only gets more brutal towards the end. At first I wasn’t too blown away too much but later on the show presents itself as being rather unpredictable and able to catch audience members off guard with all the deaths and plot twists.


But unlike works such as Another, the show doesn’t go all out with trying to make the series as shocking as possible. A lot of subtlety is added and the show is often a bit quiet and less dramatic compared to a lot of anime of this calibre. The tone is often sombre and serious, comparable to some western works such as Sicario than anything loud and dramatic. The pacing is also slow at times and the show itself is quite atmospheric, allowing audience members time to take in the feel of the show’s setting. The series increases in terms of intensity with every episode but still keeps its tone relatively consistent throughout.


Every episode (with the exception of 4 which acts as a breather episode) has a part to play in the overall plot of the series. However my biggest qualm about the series would be the ending. Every single episode towards the second half of the series seems to build up to a bombastic climax but the series never seemed to provide that. Instead there was no showdown nor were there many deaths. It was in fact quieter than anything else. It felt more like the earlier episodes of the series. Some audiences may be a bit let down by this if they were to be expecting some showdown or something along the lines of that. It was like the final two episodes of Neon Genesis Evangelion; its thematic powerful but most likely won’t be remembered (at least not by me). Another flaw was that the show never seemed to portray anything new that wouldn’t be found in any other revenge flick or gangster film. It seemed more like a homage than anything else, a love letter to a gangster film that the writers just happened to have watched and liked. 


The characters and their voice actors all fit their roles within the grand scheme of things. Avilio is cold, calculated and sometimes even intimidating for a protagonist. Sometimes a little too cold; I was finding it hard to relate to him as his sole motivation was revenge, but later there were some moments that showed that he still had some life in him. Nero was more "human" compared to Avilio, leading to him almost being a complete contrast to him. But by far the best character in the series is none other than Fango. Imagine Ladd Russo mixed in with the craziness of The Joker and you have this crazy gangster. This character is so over the top that you will either love him for bringing some Baccano esque insanity and humor into this show or you will despise him for ruining the sombre mood brought forwards by the show from the very first episode. Nevertheless he is an outlier among all the other characters who seemed more down to earth. But the show also brings another problem to the table; the other cast members don’t feel as memorable as these three. Some characters actually perish before we’ve gotten a chance to know them and this diminishes a lot of their memorability and value.


The biggest flaw 91 Days offers is its animation. A lot of the fluidity and creativity we’ve grown to love in certain anime is lost here and the show feels like its on a budget. Inconsistency is prevalent and off model shots are visible in many scenes. This isn’t too bad considering that Studio Shuka is a relatively new studio, however more should be expected from a Studio that was in charge of the highly popular Durarara series.


However the lack of animation quality was made up for with the music. It’s very reminiscent of old gangster flicks and compliments the mood of the entire show. Sometimes it intensifies when some of the more violent moments are shown. I’m not an expert with the music component of shows but if you like soundtracks with a lot of calm, collected tunes and violins playing in the background, you’ll love this.


Another thing to add would be the show’s overall setting and world. The 1900s prohibition setting was well utilized here through its vehicles, to the prevalence of alcohol, to various store fronts and so on. In fact one way to tell how well the setting is shown to us as viewers is to watch the opening credits in the first episode as it presents shots of various different places and activities that would be visible in such a time period. Its architecture is also very unorthodox from most anime out there, which tend to dabble in the usual retro or modern era Japanese architecture or one that is very stylized. The show is grounded more in realism but due to some of its characters it doesn’t forget that it’s an anime.


I was pleasantly enthralled from start to finish by this show. It’s a nice breath of fresh air to finally get something that’s more realistic and more devoid of the usual anime tropes in today’s anime. There are no magical elements in this show which is something I was really surprised by; usually modern anime would include a lot of magic, time travel elements and so on. It’s an outlier amongst the cesspool of mediocrity that summer seems to have given us and well worth the watch as a result. Anyone who is a fan of revenge thrillers or crime dramas with gangsters in it should give this one a try.

91 days is a historical drama anime that sets in the Prohibition Era of alternate United States . I was really hyped for this anime since the start of the summer season and boy did it showed. The anime gave us a an amazing presentation of the grim world of the mafia, somewhat realistically resembles what mafia families are like.
Story: Its your standard revenge story but its somewhat more deep and personal alongside the character arcs and why the main character was so driven to achieve his goal into killing his family murderers
Art: The art style reminds me of Durarara!! and Baccano. Color palates thatsometimes fit within the scenes well including the dark and somber moments.


Sound: Pretty Good overall, it plays like a film noir but not as a classic noir however. The sound design are pretty good to listen to especially the opening theme and the ending theme as well.


Characters: You can feel the life into the characters if that makes any sense. I feel like there much realism into the characters itself and not too over the top anime-like. Characters are well polished and their and each of their own motivations helps strengthens the story even more. Personally they are the highlight of this anime


Enjoyment: From start to finished, i liked this anime even though its your standard revenge story but the characters itself proves itself you don't need narrative to tell the story its the characters


Overall: Pretty Awesome i would say about this anime. However i felt like it never lived up to its own hype as it did show some promise this year of anime. Sadly, another good anime with wasted opportunity

Prohibiton Era and a WHOLE LOT of Bloodshed and Revenge
91 Days is a mafia-revenge story of one Avilio Lagusa voiced by Takashi Kondou and really 91 Days breathes in that classic mafia story a la "Godfather" from the aesthetics to it's similar plot beats.
Before LA talks about the "classic mafia" elements of 91 Days...let's get to the technicals.
For the most part, the characters all have the distinct characteristics, though yes it has that classic mafia cliche characters, from the one who wants revenge no matter what Avilio, Corteo voiced by Soma Saito, Avilio's best friend who gets roped into all this, Fango voiced by KenjirouTsuda, a no-holds bar unpredictable madman and leader of Orco family to Nero Vanetti voiced by Takuya Eguchi, one of Avilio's targets. If anything the plot can really kill off any character it wants to due to the nature of 91 Days and being a mafia-revenge story and all, the only two characters who have some sort of plot armour are Avilio and Nero until the finale (considering the anime poster...it's to be expected). LA can overlook it as well...91 Days is a revenge story...really we just don't know if Avilio's revenge will get him and Nero or BOTH of them killed off which makes the plot armour to these two rather unpredictable. In terms of character development, again due to the nature of these characters dying left, right and centre, you'd expect the deaths to be meaningless, unless your a main character or a part of Avilio, because certain character do get the shaft and they were developed quite nicely before their brutal exits...LA can't say who as that goes into major spoilers but you know the ones. Ultimately, even with the nature of this anime, it keeps it balanced and focused on it's characters, the development does focus on the characters who are crucial before their untimely exit but what development they gave is still enough for LA to care and it increasingly show Avilio's revenge to be more destructive and "nothing to lose" for him to succeed. Revenge is a typical motif in 91 Days and quite clearly shows that revenge leads to destroying others around you as well as yourself and it's shown as a manifestation of this theme most prominently in Avilio.


In terms of animation by Studio Shuka, well it really feels like Prohibition era American mafia film styled animation, the character designs are well detailed and the gunfights are crazy to say the least. If the aesthetics to 91 days is anything to say, they invoke the classic mafia movie styling and LA would praise 91 Days for that quite easily. Though when it gets really dark, LA couldn't even point out who's who...yes even in gunfights but you LA's deal...we kinda NEED to see in order to see.


The voice acting, well considering that there are lots of *ahem* Engrish *cough* at times, nonetheless, when the voice acting gets serious, it gets serious. LA's favourite voice actor easily goes to Kenjirou Tsuda as Fango as his unpredictable volatile nature was a BLAST to see. There isn't much to say about the voice acting besides, it was great across the board and didn't stray away at any point with 91 Days serious tone, again keeping with the classic mafia tone.


In terms of plot twists, really the plot twists comes in the unexpected/expected red flagged deaths, yes LA was rather mixed with these as 91 Days had a habit of trying to get us to be invested in some of these off-beat characters, then gives us some hint that they're gonna die soon, it didn't happen to EVERY character, just something LA noticed, the other plot twists comes in if any of the Vanetti family came to discover Avilio's secret plan that might jeopardize his revenge plan and this easily coincide with the "unexpected deaths" plot twists as well. Avilio's plan however is pretty rock solid until the finale, as most of the deaths are either intentionally cause by him in the name of revenge, without leaving any trace of Avilio in the process, a shadow behind the works as it were.


Now LA keep saying "classic mafia" and really that is really where 91 Days might slip for some people, LA still enjoyed it nonetheless, having something of an original anime with this kind of theme to back it, but for others it being a "classic mafia story" can lead to TONS of cliches within this genre and thus can be easily predictable what gonna happen to it. This "flaw" really is the only "flaw" LA picked up while watching 91 Days as once LA picked up some hints, LA KNEW who was gonna die (not always but you get LA's point).


The finale...well it wouldn't be a mafia story without a massacre to go with it and there is A LOT, but from the focus to the families assimilating one another due to the result of Avilio's action really just to Avilio and Nero by the end of it and the fate of the our main protagonist is left nearly ambiguous bringing in that classic mafia cliche again, but it does really bring about what revenge can do to you which is manifested in Avilio but going by what the finale gave us, this "cycle" ends in Avilio.


91 Days is by all means an intriguing and refreshing anime with it's classic mafia setting and a revenge story. LA quite enjoyed it even with it's cliches, as well as it's interesting characters who have a target on their heads. Avilio's revenge leads to suffering which brings about more suffering.

91 Days is one of those shows where the premise immediately grabs your attention, but leaves you cautiously hoping to yourself "They better not screw this up..."
Well fear not, because 91 Days delivers with a compelling story about crime, deception, and a quest for revenge in a chilling 1920s American Prohibition setting.
Shuka may have went into this show with a limited budget, but they utilized what they had to work with and made a very well put together show. 
While held back in animation, Shuka was able to utilize strong cinematography, mise en scene, atmosphere, and music to hold everything together and deliver in theend. \n\n
The story continued to up the ante and get even crazier each week. Towards the end I was repeatedly shouting "WHAT THE HELL?!" at my computer at every cliffhanger we were left with, and in the end we received a satisfying conclusion.\n\n
91 Days is just a damn good show. Plain and simple. Watch it.

Something that genuinely bothers me about a lot of brand-new anime that focus on adult-situated subjects is the lack of allowing the audience to gather everything themselves. They spoon-feed the story to the audience, aside from allowing them to use their brains. However, there are the very few that don't do that. I believe that this is that 1/1,000 series that lets the audience use their brain, and figure things out on their own. That is by far the most unique thing about the entire series, however, there is so much more to talk about when it comes to the most underrated show of thelast year.


My favorite thing about this anime is the magnificent opening theme, "Signal" by TK. The song itself was so catchingly lively, yet so melancholic and beautiful. I could listen to it for hours on end, and now it has become probably my second-favorite opening of all-time. I know it's a bit of a stretch for a lot of people to say that this was so good of an opening that I would even say that it's upon that list. However, it's my opinion at the end of the day, and the 91 days opening is on my list for my favorite opening themes in anime history.


The animation done by Studio Shuka was great. They genuinely put 110% into making this series feel like a classic mobster anime, which hasn't been done this well since Baccano! back in 2008. However, what this show does better than Baccano! in my opinion is establish the setting of the story, which it does surprisingly well. There is always an eerie atmospheric presence luring in the shadows of each scene, which made you question "what was going to go wrong." The character designs as well were very interesting. I don't know if I would say they were unique, but they definitely were quite interesting to look at, especially Fango's. Fango was a creepy character which was done surprisingly well in the midst of the series.


Another thing I'd like to mention is the fantastic voice-acting done by the dubbing cast. I watched this series in it's English Dub, which was fantastic. They all emulated accents and dialect in a manner that few shows I have ever seen have been able to replicate. Everyone working on the dubbing for this series, from the cast themselves to the ADR Directors, did a fantastic job. This was, in my opinion, one of my favorite dubs. Stellar work Funimation!


One thing that this series surprised me with was the amount of focus on plot instead of simply focusing on characters. This show had serious emphasis on the story rather than character development, which was both a good thing, and a bad thing. Disregarding that much, the story was quite entertaining, from it's dark themes, to it's more light-hearted scenes, to the background of our main character, Angelo Lagusa. Learning about the story on why Angelo is even trying to do what he will was interesting enough, but seeing how strongly he simply to do it just shows how much he cares about this. The falling to darkness for Angelo was prevalent throughout the plot, as you can tell just how much he cares about this. Not only that, but the story's development throughout was nice and slick. I must also say that the story was slow-paced, but it worked well... for the most part.


Now that I've brought up Angelo, I feel like now's a good time to bring up the characters in the series. Angelo, our protagonist, is a troubled young man with simply nothing to lose, and one goal on his mind: Kill the Vanettis for what they did to his family. Seeing him plan everything out to eventually get what he's wanted all this time was really interesting. He was purposed character done right, because you could simply tell how much he was willing to give up in his life just to get revenge. Not only Angelo, however, but his partner and secret rival Nero Vanetti was also really likable throughout the series. He was super entertaining, from his foil to Angelo, being more upbeat than Angelo ever was, but he was also a really likable, nice, and trustworthy dude who didn't want to be involved in all the gang stuff. In fact, it was made quite evident that he didn't want to continue being a part of the Vanetti mob. I should also mention Angelo's friend Corteo, who was really likable, as he was just a good friend to Angelo, but it felt like Corteo lacked in development. Similarly, Fango was a really entertaining crazy dude, who just lacked in development. Aside from that small issue, most of the characters in the show were at the very least decent.`


However, you have to take another look at this review before choosing my verdict. Assuming that I found this show flawless would be a poor assessment, as frankly, I did have some minor problems. For example, most of the characters in this show lacked on so much development that it hurt. For example, Fango was so bland of a character in terms of development, despite him being such a fantastic "creepy guy" character. His character, along with Corteo, could've been done so much better throughout the course of the series. It's not a game changer, but it was a bit annoying how they didn't get that much backstory given to them.


Despite that being annoying, my biggest problem with this show was undoubtedly the same thing that made this show so unique in the first place- the story. Though it was fantastic in it's execution, it was still quite boring at times, as it was quite confusing, to the point of pure boredom among the audience. That may just be me, because I have yet to see anyone else admit to being confused by a lot halfway through the series. Regardless of that much, it was still baffling to me how something would confuse me on such a level that actually wasn't speaking of how the team behind Skelter;Heaven and Mars of Destruction got their budget.


Besides those insignificant issues, this series was still fantastic from it's gorgeous animation, to it's interesting story and characters, and utterly magnificent opening theme.Good crime dramas are a dying breed, especially in anime, but this show may just bring back the medium in my book.


Later!

Preface:
Occasionally, we get that one anime that could as well have been something else. Occasionally even, it could have been an American TV show. 91Days sure does remind you of that and, as a result, 91Days feels un-anime. Fortunately though, it _is_ a bit of a breath of fresh air and doesn't feel like a kneejerk reaction to the current state of the industry, attempting to save us from moe, unable to save itself from a financial disaster. It's no Under The Dog and to be honest, every time a project like this comes up that's seemingly more Western, a good portion of anime fansseems to assume just that. 91Days did not call your waifu a bug-eyed whore, chanting "USA! USA! USA!" on top of her corpse. Under The Dog did. There. Go fight that windmill. I'm sure it'll be a respectable foe.


Unfortunately for 91Days though, it's also hardly among the greatest I've ever seen despite showing promise.


Also, this review contains spoilers. No individual scores though.


Writing:


The plot, technically speaking, is solid. The premise is simplistic. Masked men kill Avilio's entire family so he wants to see all of them dead in return. From that simple point on, you could go many ways and branch out. Unfortunately, 91 Days doesn't really do any of that and instead decides to keep being just that simple and restrained. For instance, there is little engagement from other characters and the plot is solely focused on Avilio. One could argue that makes sense as he is the key player. Quite frankly, that's not exactly it though. He's the only player. He is the only one on the move and that turns the entire matter into a rather one-sided affair. In other words, 91Days lack depth and complexity.


What really, really hurts the show is its protagonist who never changes. He never doubts himself for one second, his revenge is a straight path and little else. That's not always a bad thing per se but once again, you're not exactly selling a complex, engaging character here or a plot highlighting several aspects.


The acts of revenge themselves aren't even that bad. Quite the opposite actually, they are the highlights of the show. How will Avilio kill several people, highly guarded, in succession while getting away with it? That's an interesting question keeping you on the edge of your seat and the writing is clearly clever enough to come up with tricky scenarios and equally tricky ways of getting around those. The element of surprise, more often than not, is on 91Days' side. There admittedly isn't much of a battle of wits as the opposing side is way too passive for its own good but Avilio's hurdles are steep and seeing him overcome those and decimate those waning themselves to be on his side is a great source of entertainment. There's a bit of a goldmine of keikaku doori to be found with this one and that is very laudable.


That, however, isn't much of an excuse that Avilio has absolutely no personality whatsoever. There are traces of that every now and then but largely, he remains a flat character, going through the motions. Yes, that's what his character description intentionally states but it does not make for compelling character writing. At all. At the end of the day, you want to see the plans play out and little else, so whenever that isn't the case, the show suffers massively from pacing issues. Who cares about Corteo worrying about Avilio for an entire episode with the plot meanwhile being on a standstill? I certainly don't. Emotional investment is practically nonexistent.


Sadly, while Avilio doesn't fare well as a character, the same can be said for everyone else involved. Corteo exists. His entire role in the show is to be the one human factor at Avilio's side, tossed into a world where none of the likes exist. From the very beginning on, it's apparent that Corteo is just there for the element of tragedy and nothing else. He did surprisingly well with killing Fango but given that that was yet another Avilio-driven action, it only gets the point across that Corteo is a character solely defined by his relation with Avilio, unable to function without him. Barbero, too, exists. He voices his suspicions but that's about it. The Barbero Corteo thing got absolutely nowhere at all and he, too, is entirely bound to another character, namely Nero. Barbero admittedly gains some points for being competent and perhaps the sole voice of reason in the show but never really succeeds with it. He's a passive element that's meant to be taken as a potential threat to Avilio but with absolutely no intention from the writing's side to get that anywhere, the entire subplot is all bark and no bite. Which could also be said for Nero. Even when Nero gets to be the boss of his family, he doesn't do anything. He might as well not have been the boss. There is only symbolic value to be found with Nero rising to the top before being robbed off everything but that's about it. Nero, too, remains largely passive. There are some attempts at humanizing both Avilio and Nero  along the way, take the entire showing magic tricks to kids thing or Avilio being really bad at driving but it's little, barely matters and the attempts are so obvious, it's kind of amateurish. With Fango, we have some tonally jarring issues as he is entirely too cartoonish for an anime that aims to be as grounded and realistic as possible. And yet, amusingly, he does leave the strongest impression among a pool of characters with no impetus on their own and barely any relevance to the overarching plot. At least that can't be said for the madman. The rest of the characters have names but little else can be found.


The character interactions aren't even particularly bad and the dialogues can be snappy at times, yet the main issue clearly boils down to these characters having been constructed with the sole purpose of being killed off. Some character relationships here and there so the tragedy of loss gets across but individually, they are weak. They are all part of a huge collective Avilio needs to get rid off and are sadly treated as such. The characters aren't individual human beings rather than roles. Frequently the same roles even.


So whenever 91Days tries to be a human drama, attempting to tell us something meaningful, it fails. And while there are some poignant moments, they are never really enough. It doesn't come close to, say, the Sopranos' deeper instances, occasionally dipping into existentialism. When, after several seasons, we have Tony ask himself "Is that all there is?" and seriously attempting to think things through, that's a powerful moment. 91Days, by comparison, feels rather hollow.



Given that the anime is essentially one big revenge plot, the payoff certainly tends to play a big part. Yes, the journey also matters but the premise, from the very get-go on, is one to care about results. Things can and will get very frustrating, however, with the anime itself stalling progress. There are plenty of instances where Avilio could have killed Nero but refused to do so, with more teasing than actual consequences being the result. There is reason as to why Avilio spares Nero until the end but given that that's the ultimate goal of the show, it feels like a huge anticlimax and a lot of postponing during the journey. And Nero potentially killing Avilio but perhaps even not, we'll just leave that for the audience to decide, was a huge buzzkill. But does it even matter? Isn't revenge ultimately pointless? Isn't there something to learn from all of this? Aren't the true 91Days the corpses we made along the way? 

Oh, wait, it does matter. Well, too bad.


There admittedly was some melancholy to the montage at the end of two killers who took everything from each other sharing a journey of bliss, even building up trust towards each other, only for things to end... whatever way they ended. It still doesn't make up for the 1,5 minutes of wave-watching I had to get through but at least the waves were properly animated. Yeah, I was just as surprised.


The "Revenge is bad and doesn't really make you feel any better. It's all pointless." moral lesson also felt tacked on. Yeah, who would have thought? I, for one, prefer my "Nero shot a bird as he dislikes things that are alive and more expressive than Avilio. Avilio got sick of being even remotely human and turned into a pineapple can. Nero then traced back his own footprints and took off to Hawaii." interpretation. Now that's got some spark to it. Moreso than symbolic footprints at the very least.



Audiovisual Execution:


The direction rarely ever excites although there are admittedly laudable attempts at times. The entire behind the curtains affair with Corteo killing Fango was really well-done for instance. Moments like those are positive surprises but few and far inbetween.


Which brings us to the rest of the visuals, art, animation, you name it. Shuka is Omori's new studio and in case you've forgotten, they were in charge of the Durarara!! sequels, with those ones' visual execution reaching the heights of mediocrity, oftentimes not even that and at their worst, the production problems got really, really nasty.

91Days isn't quite as bad as that but with its uninspired, just functional character designs, it's never been a good-looking affair to begin with and the production melt-down offed what little chance it had to impress visually. It was bad enough for the production to require the stalling of a recap episode. You're not watching this for the sakuga fx during heated gunfire or lively character acting, I can tell you that much.


For better or worse, I seriously, absolutely do not remember the OST. Take that as you will. No unqualified statements from my side of things then.



Bottom Line:


With all that said, I can't really fault 91Days too much. It never does anything terribly wrong. None of the characters are annoying. I sincerely liked how, at the beginning, they tested the quality of the alcohol through its color. There was no exposition on that as it would have been the case in most other anime and that really goes to show that there is some fundamental quality to be found. More often than not, it's an entertaining little thing. Apart from some glaring issues, there is little it does badly. It also doesn't do a lot right however.


What can be said is that you can't make much of a mistake by watching it. You could also always do better though. It works as seasonal entertainment where beggers can't be chosers but specifically going back just to experience the better moments of 91Days might be a bit of a fruitless undertaking.


At the end of the day, it's mediocre. Admittedly at the decent end of the scale of mediocrity but oh well. There is some goodwill to be found as well as base competency down the line - but never too much of either, hardly making it beyond the premise of "These people must be killed.". Avilio never really felt like a character that got out of his wardrobe from back when he witnessed his parents' murder - and quite frankly, the same applies to the writing, never really leaving its familar ground, never really leaving its wardrobe either.

* CAUTION MAY INCLUDE SPOILERS*
       I really enjoy the gangster/mafia anime series. However, this anime was not able to wow me the way I would have liked it to.
 I felt as though the main character (Angelo) was a bit boring and that they didn't build up his character. While the antagonist (Nero) had been a likable character with charming qualities, despite this, it may have been done on purpose to show how much the death of his family had affected Angelo and his emotions. Even so, there could have been more character development focused on Angelo.Also, the story fell a bit flat.I do not think this was due to the overall plot, but that there simply was not enough surprising or dramatic development (except for the parts with Corteo, those were pretty good). \n
       But, for a 12 episode series I do think it was pretty good. Just not exactly something that I would want to re-watch multiple times. Although I do recommend that you give it a watch to see the good attributes of the anime.

One of the most misconception 91 Days confuses newcomers about is its false comparison with Baccano!, I'm not saying those who enjoyed Baccano! wouldn't like this one or vice versa, it's completely irrelevant to that. What I'm trying to get at is those series have less in common than they appear to be. Aside from the setting, there is nothing else of much notice to link the two.
Another common question that goes through the head of newcomers is the length of the series while heading “91 Days” one would easily assume the series would have 91 episodes, but no.
91 Days is a 12 episodes longshort story that covers roughly 3 months, thus the 91 days, is it enough might you say? 91 days sounds more like a recap if told in 12 episodes but isn't that the same with all stories? This is a story about revenge, decisions made on bullet time speed, one flicker and years of planning might fall off. This is a story about redemption...


- Story (8.3/10):

Living a fun happy life until the night of the massacre, Angelo witnessed the murder of his parents and younger brother at the hands of a mafia group called the Vanetti family. Making a run for it at last moment and remained silent in hiding.

7 years later he was sent a message giving him the signal to start the long-planned revenge that started by him infiltrating the Vanetti family as a fresh member, climbing the ladders and taking down his family's murdered until he makes it for the top dog, the Don of the family. Along with his path to revenge, he becomes the best buddy with one of the murderers with only makes it far more emotional and hard to finish what he started. Would he disregard his feelings? would he leave everything behind and start anew? These kinds of questions happen to pass through your mind every so often while watching this show for how characters interact with one another.

The story follows a linear path, no excessive flashbacks, and no rushing through the events. The protagonist plays his moves carefully and plans further steps ahead of the viewer every moment.

I really think that 91 Days stands out from other similar shows/movies with its fresh ideas that make up for the minimalistic cliché, as it draws heavily from the likes of The Godfather franchise.


- Art (8.5/10):

I'm very open-minded about different art styles, and one that I don't get to see very often is this generic simplistic art style that represents people from western countries the best, it goes really well with the Victorian and prohibition eras, it adds a lot of realistic feel and depth to the characters as there are no overkill eyes that seem to cover half of the face or a super Sayan hairstyle that's out of this world. Everything adds depth to the era and help convey the message.

The animation was good, above average most of the time but at its best on highlight moments, gun shootouts, knife fights, and hand to hand combat seem fluid and realistic, no over the top speed and nothing non-worldy.


- Sound (9.0/10):

I have to come straight and say this, this is one of those shows where the DUB is ways better than the SUB. Going through the prohibition era again, they absolutely nailed the accent, I had little problems with the female voice acting where it sounded very forced sometimes, but the main cast that had 90% of the show focused on them was just amazing. The soundtracks and sound effects were stunning as well, puts you in a strong mood to wearing a tuxedo and buying a luxurious classic vehicle and go for a hike on the countrysides.

I'm a begger for great opening and ending theme songs, and this one didn't disappoint at all. from the same artist(s) that made Tokyo Ghoul's and Psycho-Pass' theme songs. One would argue it doesn't fit the tone of the era, but it really suited the theme of revenge with its dark tone.


- Character (8.0/10):

Those weren't the best characters out there, but damn they weren't the least annoying, everybody was likable on their own way, aside from a few that were supposed to be disliked. They really pushed the boundaries and made you see the enemies, the people that killed the protagonist's family as humans, they feel for each other, they love, they care about their loved ones as well making you question morality in Angelo's revenge.


- Enjoyment (8.5/10):

There were those moments that really made me invested so much in the show I could have sworn I wanted to give this one a greater score if it weren't for some downfalls. Almost all episodes ended with a twist worthy of making you start the next episodes until you run out of them, a solid crime Anime right there.


- Overall (8.5/10):

This one would be a hidden gem especially for The Godfather fans, it really is a solid crime show, covers a lot of historical themes and focuses on the might of mafia families and their powers, I would absolutely recommend this if you're in the mood for some old school crime thriller show.

91 Days is a perfect anime for fans of the Prohibition Era. It's true that it doesn't stand up to the king, "Baccano!", but it reaches a good spot, good enough to be mentioned.
Talking about the Story, its a good drama and it rolls from episode to episode. It has a good pace. This only fails to the later episodes where they kind of need to rush the story so it doesn't feel heavy. Story and Characters are the best this anime has to offer. The characters have nice backgrounds and plots. You either feel for them or you relate (relate in a certain perspective,not because you are a gangster of any kind...i hope).


The fights are pretty dope!A lot of tension, smart moves and realism. You will not be disappointed.


Probably what gets this anime down its the animation. Sometimes it feels flat, dark (meaning you can't see) and the background images normally are not animated.


The music is not that memorable. You may like the OP and the ED and some themes but I don't believe you will stick with it for too long.


Overall, the enjoyment is naturally outstanding, you will be on the edge of your seat/sofa/chair for at least most of the moments."91 Days" knows how to present itself to the audience.

Imagine. Baccano without the random time skips and junk and instead of Firo, you have a crazy, revenge bent shell of a man named Angelo. You've got a lot of the storyline down.
91 Days is a gritty anime about the mafia in Italy during the 1900's. This anime is more geared towards adults so it would be understandable if this anime isn't exactly your cup of alcohol. 
Story: 9/10
The storyline is amazing with your daily dose of action, bonds of friendship, and dun dun dun moments. Here's your overview!
A once lively and wealthy boy, Angelo Lagusa now is an empty shell of a man whohad witnessed the mafia take everything from him. His father had gotten mixed up into a mafia family's business and was killed along with his brother and mother. Angelo was lucky enough to be able to escape but had to live under a different name and go into hiding. His house was then burned down and all evidence of the murder was lost and labelled as a tragic fire accident. Angelo, now named Avilio, receives a mysterious letter telling him the names of the people that had killed his family and ruined his life. With a new purpose, Avilio sets out to infiltrate and kill the men that had taken everything, in a dangerous revenge mission on the wrong side of the law. Will he succeed or will Avilio find that all that awaited him at the end of his journey was death?


Art: 7/10

The art style definitely fit the gritty and adult theme of the anime in a very Baccano style. It used mainly darker colors and realistic palettes that helped with the mafia feel of all the scenes. I commend the producers for their shading as there were a lot of shadows in the right places.


Sound: 8/10

This anime, being set in the 1900's, has a matching soundtrack. Each track has an older feel to it that helps to add that extra touch to each scene.


Character: 9/10

The characters were very lifelike and a few were quite relatable. Each one has great depth and they develop nicely. The character's interactions with each other just adds to how lifelike they are as well as the lifelike movements. Each one has plenty of flaws that is very refreshing, especially with all of the overpowered characters anime has been producing lately. These flaws are what make you so attached to these characters which is another reason why I enjoyed this anime.


Enjoyment: 9/10

This anime was able to keep me at the edge of my seat as there were many moments were it seemed as though the characters were in a pinch. Avilio's journey was especially interesting as you're constantly afraid to see if his plans fail. In the mafia, death is always right around the corner.


Overall: 8/10

This is a great anime that I recommend you watch for those that like anime like Baccano or for those that just have a plain liking for smart but slightly off their rocker characters. I thoroughly enjoyed it and I hope that it gets more credit than it is now as I think the producers did a wonderful job.


Quote!

"Think carefully, then walk forward with purpose. The faster you rush out, the more likely you are to trip and fall." ~ Vincent Vanetti

91 Days is one of those rare series that doesn't get the praise it's due. There's a lot of subtlety here that can't be appreciated without the proper view. Naturally being a work of art like all anime, not everyone will find it to their liking. 
One of the things about 91 Days that i just loved was the masterful way Angelo got his revenge. I guess to some people it would be confusing and hard to follow. Like, why doesn't he just shoot person A and be done with it? Or why not snipe them all from the rooftops, plant bombs, etc. The pointwasn't to kill them, it was to make them feel the same pain and suffering Angelo himself had suffered when he lost his family and was forced to watch. 


There's a very strong human element to the story that is quite easily missed and had I not been truly watching and instead simply enjoying watching anime (as is usually the case) I believe I would have found the series a bit confusing in more ways than one. There's a lot of dry humor in 91 Days, personally I love dry humor especially with expressionless characters, I ended up laughing way more than I felt I probably should have watching a more morbid series. I know some people don't like that kind of humor and unfortunately 91 Days didn't really have any other kind (at least that I noticed, which I'm also guilty of). Another confusing thing about 91 Days is that is jumps from one goal to another without explaining, personally I thought that was one of the things that made it so good, it gave it something of a detective type anime feel to it, I'm all about that stuff. This could get a little weird for people in the (Who the hell is this guy) kind of way. There's also a few hinted relationships (between Angelo and Strega and his family) that just leave you with a question mark hanging over your head. The series also switches between absolutely morbid (the lasagna incident and Orco, those who watched know) and absolutely hysterical (Angelo running people over with cars on 'accident'). 


While the show has it's faults and I think to most casual anime watchers it would be a hard to understand show, but in reality this show is a work of art. It tells the story how it is and for once it doesn't change mid-way through the series and get all rainbows and butterflies and then horribly sad ending. I appreciated how human Angelo and Nero were, I loved that Angelo continued to hate Nero even though in the end he didn't want to kill him. The story painted the realistic picture of revenge and what it really cost you and those around you. It didn't make it pretty. It didn't have a happy ending (though the ending is up for interpretation). It was all very HUMAN and I loved that. I love Angelo's mastery of his skills, how he killed without regret but later on shows extreme distress after Corteo's death. Again, the human factor in this anime is the strongest I've seen in an anime in a very very long time. There's a lot of subtleties with human nature playing out in this series that I think a lot of the younger watchers wouldn't completely understand. There are also some complexities that are just beautiful to watch unfold before your eyes.   


 This is worth the watch if you tend to gravitate to the more mature or psychological thrillers but also enjoy a good laugh. 


I will say my one disappointment regarding the show was the OP. I had no issues with the music, rather it was the animation that bothered me. Maybe I'm just used to being spoiled (and even as I'm writing this I can comprehend the reason behind their decisions) but typically the OP has scenes or characters you can look forward to seeing in the anime. In 91 Days that's not the case, while this amps you up I was also disappointed because at one point I really thought the man with the glasses getting shot was Corteo (valid conclusion right?) nope, it's Angelo's dad. The OP is a mix of past events and normal mafia behavior, I was disappointed when some of the more interesting scenes never came up but understanding that the OP was filling in the blanks so to speak and showing the world that Angelo immersed himself in to get his revenge has it's merits. 


I could sit and write forever about this show but I'll wrap it up. For all of you potential watchers out there I recommend giving this show a shot, look at it through serious eyes ready to learn something about humanity instead of looking at it as just another show to watch. I will say the animation lacked in some ways but it never bothered me, it's anime so anime is anime in my opinion, it's not completely about the art and it's not completely about the story, merging the two in a way that works best for both so they can each shine together is what anime is supposed to be. (in my opinion).

Overall I really loved this show. Personally I love all things Mob, Mafia, Gangs you name it, not to mention having a deep love for historical settings in the 19th and 20th century. I was weary at first as I always am when starting new shows but boy am I glad I did. I absolutely loved this show, the story and characters were compelling and the plot didn't get bogged down with unnecessary characters and romance. Some of the cinematography was simply beautiful and I was invested the whole way through binging it in one day. I'd say if you enjoy things like Durarara, BungouStray Dogs, Baccano, or hell even the Godfather i'd recommend this to you, or even if you just love plot driven and character heavy stories. Overall I'd say this a great and quick watch.

How far will you go for revenging the death of your family?
That is the question 91 Days will work on over 12 episodes. After the loss of his family, Angelo Lagusa only has a name of the man responsible of murdering his family several years before present time.
91 Days is a rare case of a 12 episode anime that actually manages to completely tell its story, not leaving open endings for potential sequels or anything like that. And it does so nicely paced.
In a 1920's esque American mafia world setting, our story plaÿs out in the seedy underworld of the mafias. The story will haveseveral characters stories tied in to the main character's motives of revenge. Everything Angelo does is carefully planned, working his way to get deeper and deeper into the mafia family responsible of his family's death.\n\n
But the deeper Angelo gets, the more difficult things gets. Riskier gambles, people starting to suspect Angelo's background and motives.\n\n
A thriller anime that will keep you on the edge of the seat with every episode, as more characters gets introduced that fleshes out the world and rumbles the storyline with their own ploys. If you're a fan of suspense and mafia settings, this is a must watch.

Seeing as this is only my second review on this here fine establishments website i humbly ask that you try to refrain from sh*ting all over my verbal balls but do indeed ask for constructive criticism. Much love.
Brief summary: Our main man for this here pulse pounding plot is Angelo Lagusa, a melancholic young miser  that was orphaned as a result of the brutal back stabbing nature of the mafia. The plot follows Angelo on his quest for revenge but is more about the conflicting morality issues that arise as a result of circumstance from being a part of the "Family" rather than asimple black and white revenge story which added a phenomenal amount of intrigue for me.


Story: 8

What puts this show ahead for me is the feeling of unease every time our protagonist is on screen, that his revenge could really come to fruition at any moment in any episode and you want him to have his revenge so badly but at the same time you really don't as it would end the most interesting character dynamic that exists in the show. It does an excellent job of dabbling in they grey area of morality rather than having a clear cut start goal and end objective. The whole plot hinges on a "will he/ Won't he" question rather than the standard kill the bad guy, save the day approach.


There is very little fat to be trimmed from the story of 91 days with almost each episode containing three to four major events that heavily impact the overall story but if there had to be a gripe of mine it'd probably be the fact that it's kind of standard mafia movie set up. (you'll see what i mean at the end of the show)


Art: 7

I'm not much of an artist, don't know a whole pile about the fine lines people find in anime artwork but in my humble opinion the art does a great job of portraying the feeling of prohibition era America, to be more specific, the artwork had a very cool feeling to it and made me feel like a suave mofo whilst watching it. It's not a anime that requires a whole bunch of flashy animation, it does it's job in helping the main focus of the show (it's character interaction) move along.


Sound: 10

Phenomenal, fucking phenomenal. Most of the pieces used are orchestral ballads that perfect compliment the feelings of mystery and unease that are presented by our protagonists morale dilemma regarding his revenge. I didn't pay much attention to the music upon my first viewing of 91 days but i found the entire soundtrack on youtube and upon listening to it i could almost play the scenes in which these musical scores were used in my head which strikes me as having done a damn fine job.


Characters: 10

The characters, in my opinion are the driving force behind the shows appeal. Whether it's Angelo going from being a dreary sullen character to finding a reason to live and developing a sense of humor as he accompanies Nero Vanneti (Episode four remains my favorite due to this) Or Nero's usual calm, charming and in control character revealing his morale quandaries about his occupation and life.


But it's easy to prattle on about the main characters and their developments, Where the real joy lies is in the shows side characters, almost but not quite every one feels like a fully fleshed out character with their own reasons for living the lives they live be it the emotional but morally upstanding corteo, Vincent vanneti's true reasons behind why he killed his best friend or the sheer lunacy of personal favorite Fango (LLLLasssagnaaaa, remember it takes Fango to tango). But i find it difficult to write about all the characters that stood out to me in this show so take my word that it has a host of fantastic characters.


Enjoyment: 10

Pure enjoyment, Should have been anime of the year in my opinion and although it does hold a strong score i still feel as if this show was somewhat looked over this year (Yeah I'm talking bout them crunchyroll awards, you fucks)


Overall: 9

This is a show that left me with a hole in my soul when it ended as i was completely invested in the characters, their relationships and their emotions. I wanted more than 12 episodes from a show entitled 91 days and spent the good part of an hour perusing the internet with tears in mah eyes after the show ended looking for any possible way in which the show could have continued. Watch it, Love it, Cherish it.

Usually I don't like watching mafia's shows and these crime Anime but 91 days is just a masterpiece! Couldn't help but finishing it.
Revenges stories are always interesting but this one gotta be one of the best story out of them, heavy plot with an intelligent, VERY smart protagonist who keeps his cool and puts his emotions under control even when he's only inches away from his enemies. Angelo is the reason why this anime is so great! If it's another protagonist I wouldn't love this anime as much as I do now. 
Even when Angelo is so cold you still can feel his sadness, reallyattached to him and  understand his motivation. \n\n
I enjoyed this anime so much, each episode just takes my breath and in some scenes I couldn't control my tears.\n\n
Overall: absolutely 10/10

This Anime ist one of the best anime in 2016. I dont know why some people hate this anime. Its an anime without fanservice and the story is some basic.
Story 9/10:
There is a man who gets a letter from a old friend of his father and in the letter are the names of the murders of his family. Who is this old friedn We dont know it yet but is he really a old friend or is he an enemy?
This man Alvirio Lagusta is full of hate for the murders of his family and he will not step back without kill them all with hisown hands. But there are some qeustions in the anime. Overall Rating: somewhere between 7 and 7.5
Wow...I completed misread this anime. I watched the first 2 and a half episodes and I was so bored. I nearly dropped it, but I kept seeing it get high ratings and accolades so I decided to finish it. It's only 12 episodes so hey, no big deal. I'm glad I did because it was definitely worth my time.
I have a soft spot for any anime that has a Western setting or anything outside of Japan that involves lots of gun fights, booze, and characters with deplorable behavior. However, I almost always do not like Mafia stories. Maybe justAmerican Italian mafia stories (I loved Black Lagoon). They bore me. So picking up 91 Days was something I did extremely hesitantly. If you're like me and you're debating whether or not you want to spend your time watching because of that element, trust me when I say it's definitely still worth it. 


What makes 91 Days so gripping is how the revenge plot unfolds. The first several episodes are such a bore, it was a pain to get through them, but by the end of episode 5, I was hooked. After a certain point, almost nothing pans out the way you expect it. I can't count how many times I ended an episode with my mouth hanging wide open as each plot twist is so unexpected. With the amount of death in the anime you really shouldn't be surprised, but every murder is still a shock each and every time.


All the characters are a piece of shit and have just about 0 redeeming qualities except for Corteo. HOWEVER, given that this story focuses around the mafia you can't expect them to be bound by any sort of sensical moral center. I mean, these men go to church and talk about family but then won't hesitate shoot up the place in the next second. It's obviously a purposeful depiction of what the mafia was like that you're supposed to analyze, but I honestly just rolled my eyes at the hypocrisy and unabashed greed of the men.


Like I said, this is a revenge story, so you do end up empathizing with the main character because you understand his reasoning for revenge, but as it becomes his reason for living, nothing and I mean NOTHING will stand in his way or jeopardize his goal. He is ruthless until almost the very end so you'll probably experience a lot of mixed feelings and question a lot of choices he makes. 


There's a decent amount of depth to the story and significant symbolism that you can get into if you like that sort of thing. However, while the mastery is somewhat there, the overall appeal is definitely lackluster (this may be in part due to the art which I will briefly mention after this) and does not at all match up to other revenge stories like Code Geass or Gankutsuou. The ending messages are deep but nothing to leave you in awe over. It's an obvious kind of final message for revenge stories as well as a commentary on the stupidity of gang violence. 


The art was definitely the weakest aspect of the anime and at first made watching all the more unenjoyable. The aesthetic was so blasé and maybe its to fit the tone of the story (Prohibition era, Mafia, Gun Violence, etc.) but I'm thinking it probably had a low budget. I was not a fan in the least bit of the art and it is definitely nothing noteworthy. 


Still, I highly recommend! It was a decent watch.

Anime: 91 days
Episodes: 12
Genre: Action, Drama, Historical
Well this anime is so interesting that I felt like I should write a review. Not writing may get counted as a sin. xD
Synopsis:
Testa Lagusa, The Consigliere of the Vanetti Family was killed along his family in his own house except Angelo Lagusa, Testa's only son. Angelo somehow escaped and was living hopelessly until a mysterious letter comes to him with the name of attackers. Angelo then changed his name to Avilio Bruno and set his journey to get revenge. Well this was the plot. I thoroughly enjoyed the whole anime because it was revealing this and that, thisand that again and again and you're like OMG what's gonna happen next? who will eliminate whom?. The main and foremost rule to become a successful crime drama. 91 day perfectly executed it. The theme is similar to Baccano, Monster and Joker game. So why watch this? because it doesn't show the power of immortals, the madness of a cold hearted man or not some games. Its completely realistic. Its totally unique in its own way. So better try this anime. Its really good.


Art & Animation:

The art here is similar to Parasyte: The Maxim. But the theme is dark. They tried their best to make this look realistic and as for animation, the show looks decent and portrays the dark thrilling mood quite well. The best parts about the show are the character emotions as we see how they show their feelings – hatred, sorrow, pity, regret. The expression they make when they are in conflict are quite something.


Sound:

91 days has decent openings, ending and soundtracks. The opening 'Signal' by TK was so awesome that I didn't even think about it skipping. The ending 'Rise and shine' by Elisa was good too. The soundtracks are also good. When you'll hear Signal you'll feel like riding a feel train. Be sure to hop on that train. :3 


Character:

If I were to describe main character Angelo in just 2 words that will be merciless and cunning. Well he couldn't survive if he didn't abandon sanity. As for Nero Vanetti I should say he's a good thinker and careful. Then there's Fango, a Psychotic character. Corteo, Angelo's friend is a not liking problem type guy xD .Other characters didn't get importance like these 4 did. Overall I will say characters are unique to each other and each has their own uniqueness and weaknesses.


Enjoyment:

This anime is too complex yet so normal. Seems interesting, isn't it? Yes you can't tell when what's going to take place. It's very enjoying and cliffhangers they show at the last moment of each episodes are awesome. Every episode has something important and unexpected to show. If you like crime-drama, you will definitely like it. That's for sure.


Overall:

This type of anime are pretty rare. I was looking at my monitor whole time without tipping my eye petals. Its one of best anime I have seen so far. I wont say its a masterpiece, wont say one of the greatest but its still one great anime.

91 Days is a decent revenge story made unbearably excruciating by a terrible lead character, god awful animation and design and an incredibly confusing first half. Seriously, it’s the first time I had to watch a recap episode ‘cause I had no idea what the hell was going on.
Not to mention that, being a native Italian speaker, it was quite painful to see characters called “Mud”, “Bend-aid”, “Sorry” or “Cool Guy”. 
*Mild Spoilers ahead*
Story
The story itself is pretty simple, too cool for school-kun receives a letter that lists the names of the people who murdered his family 7 years ago. He then sets a planin motion to get revenge on those people and somehow destroy every mafia family.\n
The pacing is a little bit too rushed in the first episodes but definitely ok in the final ones. Right at the beginning of the story you’re introduced to a bunch of characters with totally made up italian names, you look at all of them and think “what is going on?”. It’s when they start to die that things get easy, don’t worry. But the story itself has some very serious issue, it wants to portray the cruel world of mafia during the prohibitionist era through the eyes of stereotypical anime characters, making it incredibly unrealistic. I really enjoyed the final two episodes cause it finally started to look like a mafia story, but again, some of the things that happened looked a little bit weird.\n\n
Characters\n
The only two decent characters were Vanno and Nero. Simple mobs who had a dream. That’s it.\n
And then we have the rest of totally useless characters, Uncle Fatguy and Hannibal Lecter-chan. But they’re not even the worst thing. Let’s talk about Avilio and Corteo. The first one acts like “cool people don’t turn to look at explosions”, the second one is the equivalent of someone looking for a friend on 4chan. We never know what happened to Avilio in his 7 years away from home, he just says that he learned how to steal wallets, he never shows any kind of emotion, he even does something very very bad in order to move on with his agenda. WHY?! Goddammit, it doesn’t make sense, I’m sorry but it doesn’t make sense. Revenge is something that should give you some kind of closure and enable you to move on with your life, Avilio’s revenge not only fails on both aspects, but doesn't even seem to be something he himself is enjoying. Again, WHY? \n
And then there’s Simple Guy Corteo. Simple Guy Corteo basically spent the past seven years waiting for Avilio to come back, he joins the mafia cause Avilio said it’d be cool, then he kills people cause reasons, then attempts to save Avilio. I mean, Best Friend Avilio disappeared for 7 years, but who cares? Simple Guy Corteo will always be there. Makes sense.\n\n
Art & Animation\n
Oh boy, I don’t even know where to start here. Let’s just say that everyone in Lawless drives the same car. \n\n
Music & Voice Acting\n
Music wasn’t too bad, the OP was quite decent and it really captured the spirit of the show. The music that plays in the opera scene in episode 11 is quite good too. Voice acting wasn’t the best imo, every voice kinda sounded the same.\n\n
Overall\n
Not a bad anime, per se. But if you’re expecting a realistic mafia story, relatable characters and pleasant visuals, better find something else. Also, WHY is the title 91 Days? Did I miss something?

I enjoyed this anime so much. I definitely recommend.

Prohibition, prejudice and pineapples. 91 days is an anime which had me wishing for more...
Produced by Shuka studios, 91 Days is set a world dealing with prohibition, and the Mafia. After a young boys family had been shot dead in front of his very eyes, Angelo Legusa starts plotting his revenge, a revenge that will take just 7 years to come into light.The anime follows him and Mafia-related families having to deal with the illegal transportation of alcohol and the violence between eachother. After conspiring with the man who help kill his family (Nero Vannetti) Angelo works his way up until he has higher groundthan the Vannettis. The story of 91 Days is quite complex and requires much concentration to be able to watch to know what's happening on screen. With a broad range of families and characters, 91 Days covers all aspects of the story, yet complicates the task of remembering which character belongs to which name. Although complex on the outside, this anime really only had one underlying theme, Revenge. The way Angelo hides his emotions around those who hurt him most, and how he buried his feeling in the sole purpose of revenge and building a relationship with those he hates gives his character so much more depth, which really is what 91 Days is all about.\n\n
I would be lying if I didn't say that I felt some episodes were dragging on, but really what can you do, I couldn't say if I would recommend 91 Days as a first anime to watch as it can get boring at times and leave the audience baffled as to what had just happened. But as a whole I would recommend this anime to anyone who loves the Crime, violence and mystery drama genres. I personally wasn't overly thrilled by the ending, but it did conclude to a certain extent, but I was left wondering what happened next? But overall I thought that 91 Days was a very good anime, but would I watch it again? Mabye not.

This is a story of a man who has nothing left and has comes back to hunt down those who took everything away from him. As one of the more mature series of Summer 2016, 91 days is a great anime for those who wants to take a break from the usual popular series. Angelo Lagusa who enters the underworld knowing very well that exacting revenge on the mafia means being one of them - cold hearted, manipulative and ruthless killer. We follow his revenge story and the downward spiral of his and their world. Is revenge worth it? Or is it all for nothing?



My only real complaint about this series is the lackluster animation. However, this jest is overshadowed by the great directional artistry of the show - the music that perfectly captures the tone of the scenes and the cliffhanger (or plotwist) every end of the episode that makes you anticipate on the next one. 91 Days is my pick for anime of the season for Summer 2016.

After watching 91 Days, I wanted to make this review on my thoughts on it. (I'll also try not to spoil anything that's in the story)
Story (8/10)
91 Days follows Angelo Lagusa, using the name Avillio Bruno, who has returned to his home of Lawless to plan his revenge on the Venetti Family who killed his entire family in front of his eyes. Now even though story sounds like a "oh cool another revenge story", it also follows the feud between the Venetti Family and the other mafia families, a family conflict, and rivals becoming allies. The story for 91 Days is very good, with Avilliojust following orders for the Venetti Family while waiting for the opportunity and the right timing to kill one of the Venetti members.


Art (7/10)

It's alright, this will be short, but the art is okay, the theater in the 11th episode does look good and Lawless is well, ok.


Sound (7/10)

The music for 91 Days Is good, the old music fits since it does take place in the 1920s.


Characters (8/10)

The characters in 91 Days are very good, Angelo is man who wanted to get revenge on the people who killed his family, Nero Venetti, and in the backstory, he doesn't want to mess anything up and doesn't want to disappoint his father. Corteo, Avillio's friend, is just a man who didn't want to be involved with the mafia but gets involved because of Avillio, he also has a skill to make brew which the Venettis began to sell.

Well I got to say that the storyline had an interesting base to it. I enjoyed Aneglo's cool character, and the way that his story evolved, on getting his revenge against the Vanetti family. Another good point, would be the way that the series did keep you on your feet a bit. I was a bit shocked when suddenly his attitude changed, towards Nero, and the way that Angelo went around the issue in a  sneaky manner. But on the other hand, I feel like the story was too short, and there was so much more space to involve other characters much more.

Story/Characters(9-10): 91 days story structure is a combination of the classic mafia-revenge story, and a bit of the road trip adventure. Each semi split into two archs across this series. The short length of the series makes each arch very succinct and well put together, not wasting even a single minute. The director clearly knew how to get the most out of each scene, and used a unique technique you don't often see in anime like this. He removes all internal monologue, allowing us to see the story without knowing the thoughts of our protagonist. By doing this, the twists and turns feel more impactful,and the periods of tension are truly racing, even though many of these are rather slow and calm. The only, and I mean ONLY complaint I have is an episode where a random hulk like guy appears, gets beat up and it feels like an awkward filler episode. This structure gives us a cast of strong though flawed characters that are equally likable and despicable. The characters truly show the underbelly of mafia life while trying to convince us that they are still good people. In the end, the characters feel human, which for me, is probably the best part of this story.


Art(9): The art is very simple, and very muted, which works well in the more morose setting the story takes place in. however, when color pops, it truly shines, and allows for the imagery to add to the emotional depth of a scene. The character designs are semi-reminiscent of baccanno, mainly our supporting cast, but they have a more gritty shading to them. The art, though not really something that stands out or seems truly fantastic, perfectly supports the themes and story that is being told. 


Sound (8): the sound design is honestly quite minimal, and isn't that memorable over all. However, this minimalism was a smart choice by the dev team, as it allows more intense scenes to flow naturally and hold a feeling of realism. The music that is there is often very emotional, and usually present in slow scenes to build tension in a more subtle fashion. 


Enjoyment (10): The series has a slow pacing, similar to Monster, and awards viewers with pay offs that could make the fourth of july jealous, and with characters that are truly relatable. If you enjoy the slow methodical world building of Monster, or the politics of the Godfather, you will love this story.


Overall (10): In the end 91 days, is a short inspired by western mafia tales, and directly parallels most of them. And in my opinion, tells the mafia-revenge tale better than most. This is not a series for everyone, as it is not fun, its not cheerful, and it does not give a positive message. However, for those who enjoy the darker, more somber side of life, this is a great slice of melancholy with a side of existential dread.

Among all the anime about the crime and mafia "91 Days" definitely stands out as one of the darkest and most noir ones. However, exactly these qualities are responsible for making it so unique and appealing.
 A masterfully written story of revenge unfolds in front of the viewer, as he watches the main character walk his blood-soaked path in pursuit of delivering ultimate retribution to the killers of his family.
 Having received a mysterious letter, which contained the names of the perpetrators of the crime that occurred 7 years ago, matured Angelo regains his purpose in life, joins mafia and vows to put hislife on the line to punish those who took everything from him, no matter the cost.


 The anime manages to depict Angelo's development nigh perfectly. With each name crossed out, he becomes colder and emptier inside. Still, despite his moral downfall he presses forward, sacrificing more and more for the sake of his cause. 


 The key question asked by the anime is: "Can hate be justified as a reason to live ?". The answer we receive at the end leaves the one watching rather astounded: "You actually don't need a reason to carry on living. You just live". Clinging onto his past, the main character chose hate towards his enemies as his driving force, resulting in him experiencing even more suffering and loss.


 If you want to move on you shouldn't make your life heavily  dependant on something, for someday this something may vanish, leaving you devastated. Losing the object of his hate Angelo becomes a shell of his former self, giving up on life itself. And as we see muzzle pointed at his head int the end of the anime, the camera shifts to the scenery of the ocean and footprints on the shore, before switching to the credits, thus leaving a trace of ambiguity behind.


 If you seek a solid anime about crime, or simply search for an impressive story, I'd definitely recommend  you this show.
