Keep your friends close, but your enemies closer. - The Godfather
Story
There is something about mafia series that makes my heart flutter. It might be because I have a thing for anti-heroes, bag stabbing and questionable motives. Okay now I know there is something wrong with me... 
91 days is a series (With a very confusing name) where we follow Angelo Lagusa, or rather his alias Avilio Bruno, as he infiltrates himself close to the people who many years ago, killed his family, in mind killing them all and getting his revenge. We watch Avilio get close to the people, especially one Nero Vanetti, who wasalso part of the group who wiped out the Lagusas. 

The series likes to keep the audience in suspense, though the plot moves fast enough that it doesn't get boring. It's pretty much like this: everything is fine and cool, then something unexpected happens, the suspense – what is going on? What is going to happen? Then just when you think everything is fine again, everything goes bad-shit-insane. Repeat the cycle.  

The only slight problem I had with the show, was the ending. I can see why some people would call it a ”bad ending” because of it. Don't get me wrong, personally I liked it, it was all in all solid, and naturally I have my own theories of it, which I will not be going into. The fact that they let the audience make their own conclusions, not giving us a clear yes or no, is something that is a hit or miss when it comes to viewers. (Code geass, much?) Then again, isn't a good ending supposed to be something that sticks to your mind, be the conclusion to your liking or not. 

Taking all that in to consideration, I'll be granting the story a score of 

9/10


Art 


What can I say, the art was amazing. The tone of it is very serious, and the color scale is narrow, gloomy, sticking mainly to various shades of brown and grey. It fit the show very well, giving it that sort of natural look. The character designs themselves were rather detailed, when it came to their facial features. Though I'm not a big fan of the wide chin type of appearance, in this show it worked. There isn't much more I can say about the art, I mean, it was good in the first episode, it was good all the way to the last, seems like closed case to me. 

9/10  


Sound 


Oh the soundtrack... the sweet sweet soundtrack. Who am I kidding, once again, I don't remember much of anything. Sorry people, I'm sure it was good, but it's been a while since I finished the show, and I'm just too lazy to go to and listen to two hours of soundtracks to be able to find about three sentences worth of text to say about it. 

The opening though, is pure gold. It is one of those openings that I didn't skip once during the show, and listened on my headphones even after finishing it, heck I'm listening to it right now as I'm writing this, 29.12.2016, 6:17pm. But what can you expect when the same person who did this, did the storm breaking  Tokyo Ghoul opening. It fits the dark theme of the show perfectly, the almost whispered lyrics and delicate high notes, as if they were cries of despair, still give me shivers. Oh and hats off to both the Japanese and English voice actors, they pretty much nailed it, in my opinion. (It's not like Austin Tindle is one of my favorite voice actors or anything..*cough, cough*) 

With that, I give the sound

8/10


Characters 


Okay now we get to business, if you're like me, and have a weird obsession of anti-heroes, then oh boy are you going to like these characters. The cast is rather large, taken that it's a mafia series, many characters are bound to appear. The main duo are Avilio and Nero, whom I already mentioned. Though, there are a couple other characters that were if not crucial, but at least important to the plot, biggest of all Avilios childhood friend Corteo. It's sort of weird, watching the characters form relationships with each other, forming trusting friendships, not knowing that they are lying to each other by a wide margin. It's also great to see how the things that happen during the show, not only affect the plot but the characters mentalities. Real humans wouldn't go by seeing death everywhere, murdering others and come out of it like they were on a leisurely stroll in the park, (unless you know, you're a psychopath) and neither do the characters of 91 days, which makes them so much more real and appealing to the audience. We see the character mentality slowly starting to crack when things start to swell up, to get out of hand and there is just something so satisfying about that. 

So for the characters I have to go all out and give it a full score.

10/10


I'm now going to dig deeper into Avilio as a character, if you haven't seen the show yet, I would advice not reading this and hop on to Enjoyment, as it is a spoilerific territory.


Angelo Lagusa aka Avilio Bruno. In short, I like him, I really do. Here is why: 

He is mostly a blank faced young man, but then there are those moments when he actually uses his face muscles and you just know that this guy is crazy. It was what got me watching this show, in the first episode when he opens the letter and lets out that psychotic smile.  

Avilio is a character, driven only by his motivation to get revenge, to the point that he doesn't even care about his own life anymore, he just wants to avenge their death, so much so that I strongly believe that he would have eventually killed himself, for not having a purpose anymore. 

Despite all that, he is not stupid, in fact he is very tactical, and a skillful liar. So skillful in fact, that I wouldn't mind lifting him to the anime hall of fame of liars, among such geniuses as Light Yagami and Lelouch vi Britannia. 

During the series we see his character form, he starts to have genuine relationships with the people around him, still he never lets go of that final goal of his. The audience starts hoping that he'd take another course of action, until we get to the last episodes and we see what happens with him and Corteo. We as the audience just know that that was the straw that broke the camels back. I think Corteo was much like a moral anchor for him, the only thing keeping him human. But after what happened, there is nothing he could strap his humanity on to, and he breaks and is going through with his plan no matter what. 

And just for fun, here is what I think happened in the end: he died. Simple as that. We see him asking Nero earlier on why didn't he kill him when he had the chance, he wanted to die, he would have wanted to die with his family, and if Nero wouldn't kill him, he'd do it on his own. Then on the beach as he walks past Nero, he knows it's coming, he want's it to come. That's him giving Nero permission to shoot him, as it's the same scene like the first time. Avilios back to Nero, fleeting to distance. So Nero shoots him, not because of revenge or hate, but because he knew exactly that Avilio wanted it, it was him granting the last remaining wish of a man that didn't have anything else left. 


Enjoyment 


When I started watching this show, it was an ongoing series and I think I watched around the first 3 episodes like that and realized that I couldn't go on like that. This is not a show that impatient people like me can watch on a 1 episode week pace. So I was a good girl and waited till it was over and marathoned the crap out of it. If I had continued watching it like that, I probably wouldn't have liked it as much, simply because there are a lot of elements in the plot that I would have long forgotten during the wait. But because I knew myself so well, I happened to enjoy the show pretty damn much. 91 days is one of those shows that you can't put away before you get a conclusion, since every episode contained some sort of hook to keep the audience. So in short yes I did enjoy 91 days, definitely, but even though I'm now praising it, and I remember that when I finished it I was so overwhelmed by it, I couldn't think about anything else for like a week and then I pretty much forgot it, until my friend was like ”You should do a review of 91 days” and I'm like ”Damn I watched that, yea it was great!” 

9/10


Overall 


91 days is one of the rare animes that deal with the topic of mafia, and it does it really well. Yes it has it's flaws, all series do, but nothing so major it should stop you from watching the show. The ending divides people, and some may argue that it wasn't good, but I have to disagree. 

The absolute charm of the series for me were the twisted characters, and watching they grow and evolve during the show. 

It's one of those shows that is really easy to like, much like Death note, it's something I would recommend watching if you're new to anime, or if you're trying to get your friends into it. Not saying you shouldn't watch it, even if you're an old watcher like myself. 

Plugging in numbers the average score that I got for 91 days was 9 and well that's what I was going to give it anyway, so great the overall score matched with everything else. 

9/10

91 Days is a bit of a mixed bag. It has a classic revenge-saga setup, a rare-for-anime setting in gangland 1930s America, and some really standout moments of writing and animation. All this along with a story that sometimes drags, an impenetrable main character, and some downright boring episodes. My viewing recommendation - if you want to see this show but would prefer to avoid the weaker points - would be to watch episodes 1 and 2, then episodes 8 through 12. 
I had high hopes for this series after episode 2 because it felt like the plotting was moving briskly and the writing wasreally quite good. Unfortunately the series loses steam for the next few episodes, largely because the protagonist, Angelo Lagusa/Avilio Bruno, is never explored as a character. Much is made of his implacable poker face and inborn talent for gang politics, but any moments of insight into his psyche are few and far between. The supporting characters are explored much more, and that has the unfortunate result of making them more interesting than our MC. There are two female characters with speaking lines, whose character development is very limited. This is unfortunate, because Fango's tart seemed to be set up as rather cunning and shrewd, and I'd have loved to see her with a greater role in the plot.\n\n
That being said, there are still moments here worth watching. Those first two episodes are good, and episode 8 is extremely good, largely because its focus is Corteo, one of the more accessible characters in the show. That episode had the right combination of dramatic story notes, character interactions, and skillfully utilized animation to make it the standout episode of the show, particularly its final, shocking scene. The episodes after 8 are not as good but are still very meaty, and the last three episodes finally crack open Angelo's shell, allowing the themes and message of the show to finally shine through. Violence begets violence begets violence, which is all, in the end, for nothing.

Overall, in terms of storyline, this anime has proven to somehow sustain its story properly over 12 episodes rather than having that 1 episode that feels like so much information is given, it gives you that sense that oh look this is how this guy is linked to this other guy, however as good as the story is, it is kinda cliche which is why I gave it a 9 for story. In terms of Art, its not superb yet its not like Clannad which is why it received an 8. Based on sound, the voice actors were great and all but the gunshots thatwere presented was not too fantastic, worthy of an 8. For characters, Avilio draws a close similarity to Ciel from Black Butler (Kuroshitsuji) and hence my character rating is wayy lower than my other ratings. Most characters in the series are just your typical mafia members and out to have profit kinda guys and hence a 6 only. In terms of personal enjoyment, since I started the series since the first episode aired, I was surprised that it had me drawn to continue keeping up with it rather than me procrastinating, I actually wanted to find out more. Overall, an 8. 91 Days was a great series and does not seem to have any potential for a 2nd season considering everything has been drained out, however, an OVA might be possible to display the aftermath.

This anime was wroth my time watching from beginning to end and I couldn't believe that it was this good and how come I didn't watch this when it was airing. 91 days is an amazing story about revenge and I love how thus takes place during the prohibition era that too place in the US back in the 1920's-1930's and the plot twists that occur in each episode. From the amazing Op from the same people who did the Op for Tokyo Ghoul to the most soothing End that still manages to make it so relaxing with juts a tune no lyrics. I alsolove how it follows the main character avenging his family's death on his 12th birthday and ruining the life of the person who helped out with the killings. 91 Days is a mixture of the Sopranos, Baccano and The Godfather.  It does a pretty good job through 95% of it, but in the same way the Sopranos left fans irritated by the ending, without spoiling anything, this anime will, too.   The true highlight of this anime was Angelo, the Protagonist, who reminded me a great deal of Lelouch from Code Geass.  In fact, I was thinking: "I'd like to see Angelo vs. Lelouch in a battle of scheming."  That's how clever Angelo was as a protagonist.  (Although, I think Lelouch would win.).   
Along with Angelohowever was a cast of rich characters with actual motivations that went beyond the typical "Good vs. Evil" cliche.  The main targets of Angelo's revenge, the Verittis, put family above all as their main goal, and not just "I want to be rich."  It added some depth and sympathy to Nero's character which really brought power to the story.   Of course, you did have some characters who were a bit cliche evil like Ronaldo and Fango (Who does one of the craziest things I've ever seen an anime character do.).  But, overall, the cast was very realistic and grounded.   This came off like a true mob story and not just an anime loosely based on the mob.   


If I had to knock the anime, it has to be the last 10 or so minutes of the anime.  


(Don't read beyond this as it CONTAINS SPOILERS).  


Once everything was done and his revenge was had, I found it a bit ludicrous that they were having a long countryside journey together after killing each other's family.  A moment of levity, or a small moment of reminiscing before the final kill would make sense.  But a multi-day, cross-country trip to the beach?  It kind of ruined the immersion and realism set up by everything before.  They also tried too hard to be like the Sopranos in taking the final scene of that show and basically switching it from a restaurant to a car on a dirt road, with a "Oh, what happened?" kind of open ending.  


Other than that, which hurt the anime, and why I gave it a 9 and not a 10 (plus Fango was a little over the top for this kind of story) this is a great anime you'll definitely enjoy.

This was an anime that I immensely enjoyed. It doesn't present any reinventions of the genre, but I feel like it accomplished what it set out to do: tell a compelling revenge story centered around the mafia. The plot was well focused; it didn't get lost in side stories, and there was just enough exposition and development to keep me engaged. I like to sit back and let the story drive, so if you're the type who likes to solve mysteries before their time, you may see some of the twists coming. I never did, personally. 
As far as the characters go, some people findthem lacking, especially the "protagonist" Avilio/Angelo. After watching it through, I actually thought Avilio fit the part fairly well. His family was murdered as a child, and now he lives for the sole purpose of exacting his revenge on their killers. He's an empty shell. You do get to see some inner turmoil as the plot unfolds, but I think it's rather poignant that it isn't overplayed. 


I think my favorite thing about 91 Days is that there is no true protagonist. Everyone is a double crosser, everyone lies, everyone kills. But each character is also someone's friend, a part of someone's family. I was never fully on anyone's side, but I never fully hated any of the characters either.


All in all, the soundtrack is superb, and the story feels just the right length. I would definitely watch it again just to try and see the twists coming.

One of the most prominent issues with original anime is how the story does in a medium that relies on its quirks and niche appeal. 91 Days has this initial problem as it's a classic prohibition era gangster anime. No immortal gang members, no stupidly overpowered hitmen, and no gimmicks that are often seen in most anime that make them, well, anime. While a straight to the point gangster plot is somewhat refreshing in an otherwise crazy market, 91 days finds itself being lackluster as you don't end up comparing it to anime like baccano, but rather you compare it to any other western gangsterfilm that do it much better in a more suitable medium. 


To start off with, the plot on paper is actually quite solid. We have a tale of revenge in which the main character's family is murdered by a mafia family that his father collaborated with, and he grows up trying to gain the trust of the gang while attempting to kill those involved with his family's murder While on paper this story is fine, there is this feeling where even though this anime is only 12 episodes, a lot of unnecessary things happen that aren't relevant to the plot. While there aren't any plotholes, there are many times that there isn't enough detail to really care about what goes on in the story. The pacing is actually a stronger component of the anime as I never felt that they were rushing the plot forward, but I do feel the end is somewhat disappointing and leaves a lot to be desired. 


Next, the animation is extremely dull and at times has its QUALITY moments. When I saw that this was the same studio that ended up animating Durarara's sequels, I knew immediately that animation may be a problem. Sure enough, 91 days is severely lacking in the animation department. It isn't based off of style of art, as the style doesn't explain instances in which animated characters look barely recognizable, or that a car accident looks closer to an older looney tunes episode than what we would see in modern day anime geared towards adults. Overall, the biggest disappointment with this anime would for sure go towards its animation


That being said, the sound is actually fairly good at setting the atmosphere. TK has never disappointed in the music department, and the background music does a very good job creating a setting of prohibition America. The only concern is that while the music always seemed to fit the mood, it's very subtle and nothing really stands out musicwise aside from the OP. 


The characters are a mixed bag. On one hand, these aren't your cookie cutter trope characters that only show personality that resembles their archetype, but on the other hand, none of these characters are really competitive against the likes in which this show can be compared to (baccano, black lagoon, any western gangster film). The main character is an anti-hero who has no real development, which isn't a problem as he's sort of a force of nature. There are a lot of characters that are introduced which are forgotten very early on, and you only really feel two characters are fleshed out well (Nero and Corteo) while the supporting cast does very little to make you involved with the exception of Fango. Another thing to note is that the characters don't particularly have unique personalities, and their interactions with each other are quite standard.


One of the things I noticed from watching this anime was that I never really cared what was going to happen right after each episode. While there were cliffhangers that piqued my curiosity on what would happen next episode, I found myself not wanting to continue and forced myself to watch the remaining episodes. It's not so much that this anime is bad, but it's very hard to casually watch it without paying attention. Add on the fact that it's quite boring at times, and you've got a show that requires your undivided attention while being just boring enough to make you not want to continue (kind of like a lecture you need to pay attention to in a class you're not really fond of). 


Overall, this anime is a breath of fresh air from all the other generic anime, and does fulfill its role as a serious original anime with a relatively new premise. That being said, this premise has been done before in western media, and its been done much better by the likes of Scorsese. If you are a fan of crime dramas, 91 days won't bring anything new to the table, but it's worth watching if you've exhausted every other option for a crime drama.

91 days (even though it doesn't even take place in 91 days, it's more like 2,555 days). Taking place in the prohibition era, this is about one man's quest for revenge against the mafia for killing his family. Angelo changes his name and joins the mafia to kill everyone from the inside without suspicion It's more than just revenge, because some other stuff happens. Either way, how is this show? Let's see
STORY
The story has some highs and some lows. When it's good, the story thrilled me. The best part about it is that one of the mafia men that killed his family is now afriend to the main character, and he's only being used until his inevitable murder. It was very suspenseful waiting for the question to be answered "when will he die?" Various other things, like "will they find out Angelo's real identity?" But on its low points, the show can feel kind of boring and slow due to the pacing and direction. It always picks up eventually, but it can be a drag at times.


CHARACTERS

Hit or miss. Angelo, our main character is this show's weakest part, aside from the pacing and slow direction. He's the very quiet and reserved type of character. While this might work for a side character, it almost never works for the main character. 91 days is no exception. Except for his vengefulness, you know absolutely nothing about Angelo. There's also a scene in the last episode where he snaps and loses his temper which was just beautiful, so he's not always quiet. Everyone else, though, very good job. One of the driving forces of the show is that Angelo actually befriends one of the mob men, but he does so just so he can die. This character was amazingly written. He was developed to the point where I didn't want him to die, and at the same time I wanted Angelo to get revenge and kill him, thus conflicting me. Extra bonus points to any show that conflicts me with who I want to survive.


ANIMATION

Excellent. These characters look and feel so real, it's great. In the first episode, thee credits are intertwined with various shots, and those shots look real. I could've sworn it was a picture taken on a camera. With the characters, sometimes when they're far away, the animators don't bother to animate their faces or any drast detail, but that's kind of normal with anime.


SOUND

Not much worth mentioning, except for the opening which kicked ass.


OTHER THINGS

The absolute best thing about 91 days is how absolutely different it is from all other anime. You hear anime and you think Japanese high school, super powers, giant robots, big boobs and such. 91 days follows no anime cliches whatsoever, and I can say without hesitation that it's the most stylistically different anime I've ever seen (that and Gankutsuou). It takes place in America, during the 1910's, with an all adult cast, none of which are Japanese. The only anime-like thing about this is the opening that's in Japanese. Major props for never delving into the supernatural or having fan service, it's 100% grounded, serious crime thriller all the way through.


OVERALL

Should you watch it? Probably. I would suggest this in a heart beat because I loved it overall, but I'm aware why others might not. The pacing, direction, characterization, and lack of focus in the plot is jarring and might turn off some people, but to me those are mere cons in an overall great show.

Following the schemes and tribulations of Angelo Lagusa from the murder of his family to his inclusion in rum running during the American Prohibition, 91 Days is equipped with a plethora of suspenseful writing and devilishly unique characters.
This isn't to say that what audiences will get from 91 Days is especially new or original, following a very formulaic plot of murder-revenge set against an organized crime background. However, the vivid characters and how they react to one another sell the series as a subtle Hitchcockian tale rife with double dealings and chess-like stratagems.
Produced by studio Shuka, it is obvious from the very first frame that91 Days was being guided by those who brought us the Durarara!! sequels, its characters easily slotting amongst the cast from Ikebukuro. Though this can be seen as recycling previous designs, there is enough anotherness in 91 Days' characters that suck the viewer in, and with the commitment of the voice cast (particularly Kenjirou Tsuda, who is far more lively and convincing in his role of Fango, than his role of Jirou Gamou in Joker Game), we are invested because we care for and remember these characters.\n\n
No individual element falls by the wayside to grandstand another, and thusly the whole of the series comes off as strong, intriguing, and even-footed through its 12-episode run, and I look forward to a continuation of what has been built here.

91 Days is ambiguous but ambition alone doesn't make for a great watch. 
Shallow would be decent one word description of the show,  while on the surface it's a 12 episodes long mafia revenge story with all the story beats you'd expect, ruthless murder, betrayal, patricide, sacrifice. But if you were to bite into this bloody pie your upper and bottom jaw would meet prematurely. The constant problem with the writing is that there's no weight at all. 
It all starts off well enough, poor Angelo's family is killed in front of him in cold blood and he's was barely lucky enough to runaway, then, seven years later he receives an opportunity for revenge. Decent enough premise for a simple story yet it quickly becomes too ambitious for it's own good. Rather soon we're introduced to three major mafia families and power struggle between them but at no point they're fleshed out enough to give a damn, same goes for pretty much every character. Corteo is probably the closest this show comes to an interesting character. Smart kid who resents mafia had to drive into crime due to brotherly bonds between him and Angelo. Unable to see his brother turn into another criminal he takes action to make it stop, only to meet a very unfortunate end. Meanwhile our protagonist is just a guy who would do anything for revenge except for the part where he kills closest thing he got to family (for revenge), kills a mafia don which leads to collapse of Vanettis he's trying to kill but then doesn't kill one of the men on his hit list just cause didn't want to. \n
It's all topped off with a classic, bothched ending, a tradition all too common in anime and manga. Spoilers ahead. Nero, one of Angelo's targets kills him... or he doesn't. The ending is too vague and needlessly open ended. If Nero doesn't kill Angelo then Angelo lives on after being determined to meet his dead friend (that he killed) and without competing his long useless revenge. If he dies then sparing Nero was rather useless and makes him the biggest asshole in the whole show (yes, bigger than Fango). Just awful. \n\n
As far as animation goes the show got style and decent colour direction bit outside of episode 1 it's hardly impressive and at times looks pretty wonky and cheap. Music is pretty good, orchestral score fits the period and while not outstanding, serves as good background. \n\n
Watch this if you want but you should watch Godfather after that if you haven't already.

this anime gives me very conflicting feelings. some aspects of it were really strong, while others i felt lacked due to the nature of the storytelling. 
enjoyment and overall (7/10): overall, the anime was good. not great. not bad. just good. it wasn't ugly to look at, the voice acting was solid, the plot was engaging, it had the right about of plot twists and a host of likable (or hateable) characters to choose from. the ending -- while i HATE cliffhangers/open ended conclusions -- fit well here and i actually felt like it was appropriate. i didnt feel like i was wasting time watchingthis anime and i might watch the spin offs but im not sure if i would re-watch it later in the future.


Story (7/10): the story was engaging but started off very "Godfather" like. ill mention this more in characters but personally, I was a little lost in the beginning episodes because of the rapid introduction of all of the main and supporting characters in a short period of time. it made following the plot and determining the importance of certain characters much more difficult. because the plot is packed with different characters, the character development takes a hit in quality, which also affects the plot. but as the anime went on, it definitely got more enjoyable and i started to really become invested in the characters and truly understand their motives. with that being said there, the anime does have its fair share of mafia tropes and cliches.


art (7/10): the fight sequences were pretty solid. i like the color schemes throughout the anime; it really helped enhance the emotions of the scenes but that being said I wasn't really wowed by anything in this area. the characters were very distinct looking and the animation didnt seem to janky but that is to be expected of all animes, not something to give bonus points for unless it was done outstandingly well.


sound (8/10): the sound design was awesome. the gun sounds were amazing and didnt sound like they were all the same gun. the soundtrack was a little boring but it fit the themes and scenes well so im not too bothered. the voice acing was done well, which is to be expected from people like ono daisuke. 


characters (7/10): like i said before, the beginning episodes kinda just dump a lot of characters on the viewer in a short amount of time, and if youre not actively paying attention you can very well miss something and completely throw you off. this makes trying to determine which characters are important and why difficult. it also messes with engaging with the plot; its harder to have some sort of connection to the characters when you dont know which character belongs to which family and who made alliances with who. the plot is jam packed with different people. but their development is compromised because there is limited screen time and the plot still needs to continue, so because of that, we see a lot of half developments or barely developed characters with potential. a good example is Fio and Ronaldo. i think them as a couple had some potential to really add some layer of drama and complexity to the story if their sub plot was more flushed out

Plot
"It was all for nothing"
This quote from 91 Days sums up the overall story. The protagonist's motive lacked in emotional depth, even though it was a classic one of getting revenge. The plot overall was complex, especially with the different family feuds, which was quite interesting. So although the plot would have been quite interesting, for me personally it lacked the emotional side which allows the viewer to immerse himself in story. 
Art
I really liked the art. The style was nice to watch, especially the people. The landscape tended to be a bit unrealistic concerning perspectives. 
Sound
The intro was nice (TK from Ling Tosite Sigure!)as well as the closing song. The scenes themselves were lacking from time to time an exciting soundtrack, but overall it was well done.\n\n
Character\n\n
Ahhh... All I'd like to say, is that the characters didn't quite have that emotional depth to them. I just didn't feel with them, nor did I feel sad or happy for them. They, and the story as well, left me pretty much cold\n\n
Overall I think it could have been an amazing Anime, if only for a bit more emotional depth and character building.\n\n

Well that was a surprise, 91 days literally destroyed all of my expectations. 8.5 from me
This anime was like the freshly baked bread, still warm, straight out the bakery as compared to the one you usually get in the store, a rare treat. 
I'll start with the most important - Story:  It's a simple enough idea that you might think will follow a linear pattern, however, as the anime progresses the plot starts deviating from that line, it involves many characters and aspects, it takes unexpected turns and the more you watch the more confused you get and yet the more you actually followthe development with a better understanding.


The characters: Complex figures with individuality that does not have to rely on exaggerated features, all of them are portrayed as people who stand for their own and each is righteous in their thinking, none is introduced as the "good" or "bad" guy so the viewer is free to decide for himself whom to sympathize with.  


The art is simply exceptional down to the last character. Very rarely have I seen an anime that does not need the emotional condition  of a character to be explained verbally. Yes, the art allows the viewer to see how the protagonists feel.


The OST and voice actor selection was also beyond adequate. Beautiful music and amazing VAs, no squeaking, shouting, meowing or quacking, no female VAs voicing male characters or vice versa, pure goodness. 


It's not perfect, it had its downsides as any other anime but it was a fresh sip of air that left me charmed and wanting to see more, like manga or continuation, and also disappointed at the same time because probably neither will happen.

 Either way, 91 days is 1 of these shows that bring me back faith that anime has not fully become all about oversized breasts, harem, school cliches, moe and tsundere etc...

Characters all had a specific role to play either being really weird or just bonding a relationship. Mainly this goes with Angelo and Nero but other characters are into this relationship as well.\n\n

If I had to recommend a drama to anyone, this would be it. I'm sure you've read the synopsis already given in the database, so I won't dive into that. I have given the story a 10, simply because it is an amazing story, duh. It's mafia-styled so there's a lot of drama, gunfights, secrets and more. I haven't seen any other mafia centered anime so this was a first and I'm glad I went out of my comfort zone for this.
The art is very good. There's some nice scenery glances we get and of course there's alchohol (mafia, duh) so they do a goodjob with that as well. Studio Shuka is known for Durarara!x2, so if you have seen that show, expect similar animation and sound quality. Speaking of sound, they do a great job with the old car sounds, the gunshots and more. I enjoyed the series and look forward to each episode. It didn't feel like a chore to watch (we all have those animes...) Overall, it's a 9/10. I can't say that the animation and characters were 10/10, but they were still high quality. If you're looking for a great drama with a lot of emotional scenes, gunfights, secrets and tension, here ya go. Give 91 Days a shot!

Name       : 91 Days
Episode   : 12
Rate         : MAL- 7.9/10, IMDb- 7.8/10, Steam- 8/10
                                                 ~Review~
The story is set in the town of Lawless, Illinois during Prohibition, where brewed liquor dominates the black market. Angelo Lagusa, a young man his family was murderedin a mafia dispute, seeks revenge against the Vanetti Family, particularly its don, Vincent Vanetti. After seven years in hiding following the night of the murder, Angelo receives an anonymous letter from a friend of his father's, prompting him to return to Lawless and exact his revenge. Under the name of Avilio Bruno, he begins to infiltrate the Vanetti Family by slowly befriending the don's son, Nero. However, in this dramatic 91-day story, revenge breeds revenge, and killing may yield drastic consequences.

A strong start but a weak finish Overall Disappointed. The story lead on to give you a sense of originality. Only to to leave the viewer with a typical revenge epic that could of been summed up in a few episodes. Instead the Audience is left with an empty and anti-climatic ending. More can be said for the Art work in this series than the story or characters.
                             For an overall score I am personally awarding thisan 6/10.

I haven't watched too many mafia-style anime, but this anime was very enjoyable for me. The plot is about a boy by the name of Angelo Lagusa who had his family taken away from him due to mafia-related business. He then begins to seek revenge on those who took his family away from him. I liked how this anime showed the main "antagonist" right off the bat and used the hatred in Angelo's heart to keep the ball rolling throughout the entire show. Angelo knows that he needs to hate Nero in order to get his revenge, but he also needs help from Nero todo that as well. I wasn't too satisfied with the way things turned out at first, but giving it a second look, thinking back to everything that happened, and getting a little help from a friend, i now understand that it all came together and everything makes sense now

I love gangster/mob story lines. So I did enjoy 91 Days. But with most short anime series that range 12/13 episodes... the first 8 episodes of this series was amazing, well thought out, and overall very interesting. Then the last few roll around and they're just boring and rushed. 
When you figure out who the writer of the letter was, I was so disappointed only because it was so incredibly obvious. it doesn't take a scientist to figure out who it was. Then Avilio, his character is honestly just boring. Of course every anime has to have that thunder type but it got annoying. 
Butthat was the point of the character I guess. There were times that did actually make me cry.

Another thing, you never really find out why Tetsu Lagusa was killed. Like it's mentioned but the writers could've thought of something so much more clever.


Overall, 91 Days was good and I would recommend it! Just don't be surprised when you are let down in the end.

Oh this show had so much promise, then just went down hill. I like great mafia and revenge stories and the story just never really got me invested. The progression was choppy and slow, character evolution never really materialized and through the entire show I was just wanting more of the it factor to keep me going that never came about. The beginning sets you up and has a great hook to get you invested but the middle and end is where it fails. If you have nothing else to watch and want to see a mediocre storyline, give this a shot.

91 Days is pretty unorthodox for being an anime series. It bucks some traditional tropes for playing it straight.
We'll get right down to business. The story is pretty traditional fare for a Mafia based story. It's set during Prohibition in the fictional town of Lawless in the United States. It's a traditional revenge based narrative that plays out for the protagonist to kill them all so that there's some "justice" in the world. It's not fancy, but it works.
The art is spot on for 1920s America before blue jeans came into style, everyone was well dressed even when they were going on murderous rampages orrioting. You had to be dressed to the 9s for this kinda stuff.\n\n
Most of the music I didn't really care for other than the theme song. It was hands down the best opening theme to all of the shows I watched for the Summer 2016 season. The effects are spot on though.\n\n
Most of the characters are complete dirtbags but still relatable and likeable. You can understand why they do what they do within the context of the narrative.

I came into this show somewhat optimistic. It has a nice premise: Set during the Prohibition Era, a man returns to town after years of being away because he receives new information into the deaths of his family. This is a revenge story, which is a popular focus in the mafia business – you leave one person alive in a killing spree and it will come back to bite you in the ass. However, the execution of this tale is terrible for a number of reasons.
The story starts off in Episode One by showing how the Lagusa Family was betrayed by the Vanetti Family andkilled – all but one, our protagonist, Avilio. The episode concludes by introducing our “antagonist” Nero – who, by the way, is the guy opposite Avilio on the poster. This automatically left me with a bad taste in my mouth as I ended the episode, because this is a revenge story and that means no matter what happens these two people are going to be alive until the end, when one or both inevitably die by the other’s hand. A lot of the drama of the show is sucked up by this rule, and it adds to the predictability of an already subpar story. If the creators wanted this show to be remarkable at all, they would have kept the revenge plot from us for the beginning of the series and let the “friendship” between the two blossom before hitting us where it hurts. Now that would have been entertaining. 


However, this show is so predictable it hurts. Sure, I was surprised in episode two, enough to keep me interested in the story and not drop it, but very rarely since then have I been genuinely surprised by a plot development. Some of this has to do with the rule stated above: neither Nero nor Avilio can die until the end. But some of it also because the writers feel the need to hold our hands so that a plot development doesn’t confuse the audience. For example, the head Don of a rival gang loves lasagna, so much so that we get reminded of this at least three times in the first six episodes. So, when his gruesome underling challenges him, wins, and then brings all of the top gang members in for a “nice” dinner of lasagna, it’s immediately apparent that the meat in the lasagna is the ex-head (Frey Pies, anyone?). The show also tries to convince us many times that Nero’s life is in danger – how can it be when he is the “last boss”, if you will, in Avilio’s revenge plan?


There are many other flaws in this story, all because the writers want to spice up the action with as much 1920s gang violence as they possibly can. There’s Prohibition style law breaking, betrayals among many different families, violence galore, and barely explained gang politics. Major plot developments can be introduced in minute 3 and resolved by minute 13. Can I not have more than an episode of suspense? Will this character be caught? Will they drive out that cop in more than a day? Character motivations are glossed over at best for most of these events and we are just expected to go with it because plot. It doesn’t help that the person I like the most is Corteo, a character that is barely seen in the first half but is probably supposed to be Avilio’s moral compass. The writers of this series are trying too hard to add edgy things and Gotcha! moments to a story that might have been somewhat decent without all of that spice. The overall story is therefore mediocre at best and predicable and boring at worst. The ending is also completely unsatisfying, unsurprisingly, even though there were a few good moments sprinkled into the last few episodes. The last episode is weak, disjointed, and pointless and ultimately left me feeling cheated and angry. 


I mentioned above that my favorite character is a background character – this is because almost every other character is complete garbage. Both Avilio and Nero are weak, horrible characters. Avilio is defined only by his need for revenge, and most of his dealings in the story revolve around that goal. Nero is a similarly weak character: he is the heir to the Vanetti family and kind of a complete asshole. The show tries to make him somewhat sympathetic with a flashback to the night he killed Avilio’s family from his perspective, but the moment is immediately glossed over because he reveals crucial information about the night to Avilio, and Avilio only cares about his revenge. Avilio is somewhat decent at lying his way out of tight situations and getting on Nero’s good side, but only a complete moron would trust someone so completely as Nero trusts Avilio is such a short period of time. This guy is asking to be killed. These characters are not convincing and, quite frankly, both of them are unlikeable assholes. 


Almost every other character is the same. Either the show doesn’t spend much time on them or they are complete moronic assholes. Nero has a small group of friends, who, I can only assume, are all going to be cannon fodder because that guy is such a moron. I’ll mourn for the dude in glasses, he seems pretty cool. Nero also has a father and two siblings, none of which are given any kind of screen time unless the plot demands it. Nero’s brother is ridiculous. Nero’s father is a pushover. Nero’s sister seems nice but easily manipulated. None of these people are given any kind of development and some act certain ways because, as stated above, the plot demands it. Some of the things these characters do are never hinted at until it happens. There are people from the other two mentioned gangs that pop up occasionally, but the most important one is Fango, who is a crazy person working for the Orco family. A lot of the B plot in the first half revolves around him and his shenanigans – suffice to say, even then, it was difficult to decide who to root for in these fights because everyone in this show sucks. He comes into a lot of power as the show progresses, and it is fun to just sit there and laugh at the morons who helped him into power and immediately regret their decision. Idiots. 


There’s not much else to say. The animation is mediocre and the color palate changes to fit the mood of the scene. The sound is not much better; I don’t think the opening fits the show very well and I was hoping for a more Baccano! type song. The story is mediocre at best and predicable at worst and the characters are very poorly developed, which only adds to the story’s problems. I don’t usually complete shows I find this many problems with, which does show that it is somewhat entertaining, and by the end I was only invested to see how the Avilio vs Nero showdown happened. But entertainment does not equal good quality. All in all, 91 Days is horrible, from story to characters to even the animation. The creators are waving a set of shiny, blood red keys in our faces, hoping that it distracts us from the blatant problems with the story and characters. Well, I wasn’t distracted. Do a better job next time.

~Second review.~
I say, I was actually impressed with this. Yes, it was short but overall had an interesting story. Hell, for all we know this actually happened during the Prohibition Era. I am still curious about his brothers whereabouts (if he's actually not dead). But this was great and the opening and ending are catchy.

‘Wine, guns, mafia and top-notch animation to boot’
Storyline 8/10 
The writers have only 12 episodes for him to slot in a tale which describes a young boy and his journey for vengeance in which they did brilliantly. 
The story itself does not seemed too rushed and not too compressed to which allows the viewers to understand the story even better at a decent pace. 
Aside from that, the storyline is not so ‘basic’ that it does not reveal everything at the first few episodes of the series which incites curiosity and intrigues the audience to think and leaves them wanting to know more at theend of each episode. 

Plot-twists and turning of events is to be expected as well, where everything might not seem as they suppose to be and can quickly catch one off-guard, most notably the ending, which I would not spoil too much of. 


Art 9/10

Given how it is still considered to be a modern-age anime, the graphics is expected to be up-to-par in which it did not disappoint. 

The characters and scenes were perfectly drawn and the colours were fitting, in which dull and low-tonne colours were used to supplement the fact that the theme of the anime centers on the underground mafia world. 

Nothing much to say about the art of 91 Days to which it was splendidly done and beautifully crafted. 

Sound and Music 10/10

One of the best soundtracks that I have heard off. Well, at least for the opening

The band for the opening is also the band that performed the iconic ‘Unravel’ from Tokyo Ghoul. The opening has a catchy tune and the slow and solemn voice of TK can be heard brilliantly where the ‘emo’ vibes can be felt from the singer portrayal of the song. 


Character 6/10

The characters are decently created but fell short of in terms of variations and exclusivity. This is mainly due to that the characters were all pretty stereotypical of the ‘mafia culture’ and that most of them speak with crude and rude languages, which does hold some merits of associating it with reality that the audience can relate to. 

The main character, Avillo Bruno appeared to be a person that has all the ideas in the palm of his hand to which it makes the character flawless and unfazed which personally for me is not a good thing when it comes to storytelling. What is there to be expected where one is already omnipotent right? 

This concept is pretty much similar to Kirito from SAO and Tatsuya Shiba from Mahouka which is pretty much as perfect as it can get and it is predictable that at the end of the day, the main character can solve the issue at hand with relatively ease. 


Enjoyment 8/10

As mentioned in the storyline of the anime, at the end of each episode I wanted to know more about the story. 

Therefore, I really enjoyed the plotline that keeps the audience to know more and there is no flat line where the story might be stalled and redundant. 

91 Days offers plenty amount of eye-captivating actions and mind-intriguing dialogues which for me, has kept me occupied and curious. Curious to know more and to quickly find out how the protagonist is able to get out of the troubles that he got himself into in a witty way.


Overall 8/10

For 12 episodes, I felt that the anime has done its job in providing the audience with plentiful of excitements and twists. Although there might not be any lovey-dovey and fan-service moments included in this anime, it is its atmosphere and portrayal of crime and revenge that captures the audience’s attention and not the bras and panties.

A good take by Anime on the Mafia life. Most characters are interesting and they keep developing through out the story. The story itself is good, it's a traditional revenge story with some twists and turns. I liked the opening a lot and the music as whole was very good.
The only problem that I had was the animation and art. I won't say that they were horrible, but I had problems looking at the anime sometimes.
In the end it's a very good Anime, and I hope that we can watch more of these takes on mafia and gangs life by Anime because 91 Days wasa good attempt.

Story 10/10:First, I'll give the very basics of this story: wealthy kid has a father who is involved with a crime family, crime family kills his family, kid disappears, kid reappears grown up to take revenge on the crime family by getting close to them. What really stuck out about the story of this show is it's setting. It is strictly prohibition era America; no AU prohibition era with fantasy-like elements, no futuristic space setting that has some kind of prohibition in place on a made up substance, straight prohibition with bootlegging crime families. As for why that is so important, personally, I always enjoyedstories of that era and the different kind of life that is impossible to live now. In terms of actual merit, and not personal opinion, the story of revenge that plays out in this show is fairly complex with its near seamless plot twists and bomb-drops, yet it's not actually hard to follow. If you enjoyed reading "The Great Gatsby" because of the setting, but wished it had some more action to it, then this anime is for you.


Art 9/10: Unless the art in a show is really bad or insanely beautiful, I'm not much of an art critic. All I'll say here is that the prohibition era scenery, characters, and elements in general are accurately and well portrayed


Character 9/10: Since this show deals with a few crime families, naturally there is going to be an ensemble cast to keep track of. 91 Days does a great job at giving you exactly enough development for each character relative to how much they are really worth caring about considering you will not be sure at any point who will live and who is next to die as the main character enacts his plan for revenge.


Enjoyment 9/10: Because of the "who will live and die" aspect of this show, possibly my greatest factor for enjoyment (that I recommend for any prospective viewers) was watching the episodes with a group of friends that all had their own theories of what plot twist/bomb drop would come next, and who would be the next to die, as well as who we want to live. 


Overall 9/10: Between the setting, story, plot twists, characters, and fond memories with my friends, I absolutely loved this show! My only grievance is with the ending: all I will say about it is that it can be left up to individual interpretation and while I have no problem with shows like that, I just personally wanted more for an ending out of a show I enjoyed this much.

Overall a great show but it got a little confusing but the characters could replace that lack because of how cool they are. They were having plot twist after plot twist in this anime and this anime had one of the best ending I've seen. The story was bad if this kid trying to get revenge when he was older; this part was a blunder, I don't want to explain it here so you have to watch to find out, but in the end I enjoyed watching this show. This is wht I call a normal show. The art didn't suit me that much forsome reason. This shows music we're the best and the charcters were mind blowing. They main charcter was cool until the end of the show, never once lost that.

DISCLAIMER: I ENJOY MOSTLY ALL THE SHOWS I WATCH, THIS IS MY OPINION DON'T GET TRIGGERED BUT WHAT I SAY IN THIS REVIEW, THANK YOU.
-STORY:This is a story about revenge, murder, and chaos. A man out for revenge for the people who killed his family and he wants them to suffer.
-CHARACTER:I think that this show was honestly great. It had a good plot with a nice build up in the beginning showing how mysterious out main protagonist was. And then putting us into the wild fire of an Italian mafia war.
-MUSIC/SOUND:The OP was greatly done by the same singer/band who did the Tokyo Ghoul OPtheme.\n\n
-ART:Art style was very nice and didn't have many faults to it, it felt like a nice fit with the theme.\n\n
Overall i'd like to say that i enjoyed this series and that i recommend it. obviously it isn't perfect but just watch it and decide how you like it yourself.

So, the basic synopsis of this show was that Angelo's family was murdered and Angelo had to watch. Angelo was luckily to escape, but years later, he wants revenge.
    So the story has a interesting concept. It's very retro 1900's gangster move ish, like The Godfather. Even the show's logo looks like The Godfather's. The story has a lot of suspense and puts you on edge. I think Shuka did a good job on progressing the story in a way, that sets the mood.
  The art is okay. The dark and monochrome pallet of the show emphasizes the mood and toneof the show.  \n
    The character development continues as the show progresses. It's kind of predictable of how the characters are going to act. There was nothing too shocking, except the end. \n
     I really liked this show. Kept me on the edge of my seat with excitement.\n
     Overall, I recommend giving this show a watch if you like your mystery/gangster animes.

Story gets a 2.  Tell me why someone would pick the time period in America known for being fun, happy, party, glamorized, etc., and make it a depressing, boring, and dull anime?  That's the first mistake.  The story itself isn't that bad, but the time period unfortunately pushes it to a 2.  
The art itself is decent, but nothing that good.  I give it a 4.  The sound gets a 7 for being pretty good.  I'll say that so far, Anime in general has good sound even if everything else sucks.
The characters were all horrible, so it getsa 1.  The main character was like an emo guy trying to be cool and tough.  "I talk in a monotone and deep voice to show how badass I am, and how cool I am."  While trying to talk tough, he has yet to get in a serious fight.  Even his so called weaker friend has more guts than him.  The other characters were obnoxious, obsessive, jealous, or weak; sometimes they were a combination of 2 or more.  \n\n
The enjoyment gets a 2 as well.  The combination of the story and characters make it really hard to watch.  The art and sound don't really make up for it either to be honest.\n\n
Overall it gets a 4.  The sound and art brought it up, but not by much.  Everything else is just so bad.

Prohibition is one of my favorite eras of American History.Everyone was going insane killing each other and what not. I also love Revenge.I'm a very fair minded person.If someone scratches my back, I scratch theirs.If someone loans me money, I'll pay them back.Or in this case, If someone murders my family, i'll kill them too, no matter how long it takes.Both of things made a story that sounded promising but it wasn't what I expected.
91 Days is about Avillo Bruno.When he was a kid,his family was murder by some baddy gangsters and now he plans on murdering them. He is friends with a guy whomakes good alcohol and Avillo somehow finds his way into the Vanetti family.And now we see him enact his revenge...for about 4 or 5 episodes.But after that we have to deal with the whole Vanetti deal


Okay, to be honest, I really wasn't paying attention to the whole Vanetti deal.I just wanted Avillo to put a bullet through Nero Vanetti's head and move along.At first.But he is not his target.He might as well have been though.Avillo and Nero are together for a while,yet the other targets that he is after takes a while for him to shoot.He gets some people here and there but he gets so involved in the whole Vanetti deal that he doesn't really get to the point of killing all of them to the point where other people that he had no intent of killing are killed nonetheless. Thus, he gets wrapped in other things, then his friend gets involved and after that, things get more and more anarchic.When there are people talking about the quarrels with other families, I try to pay attention as much as I can but it's hard.This show is like "The Hateful Eight" where there are really great show stopping moments but the rest of the movie is really boring and slow. If people were not getting shot in the testicular region or being poisoned, other things were happening like people playing songs and talking and talking and talking.Same thing goes with 91 days, but this show is actually hours longer than Hateful Eight and it also more great moments than not so great.One thing that is useless but fun is the chemistry that Nero and Avillo gain over the show. There is one whole episode where they are just traveling and despite slowing the plot it was kinda entertaining.Speaking of slowing down, This show is called "91 Days" and I can tell you it took me way more than 91 days to finish this show.(I started the show in October and now it's May)for two reasons.1.I'm a very lazy person and 2. I wanted to wait until the show was fully dubbed.Thank goodness for the recap episode that gave me a heads up about what's going on. But this recap shows the problem of the slowness that this show can have. About 4 episodes are completely summed up by the narrator in one sentence.This is mainly dealing with the whole Vanetti thing.On the bright side, when Avillo decides to do something at the very end of the series, the whole Vanetti thing is turned on its head and it was amazing to see.The ending was a bit weird though


 SPOILERS

{{{{{Long Story short Avillo completes his goal more or less but he wonders"well, what do I do now?"and then Nero comes around and says"you could just turn into a can of peaches" and Avillo is like"wow! that's a good idea!I have nothing else to do."(this isn't what actually happens;It just looks like it happened that way}}}}}


I mean the ending was good but, It could have been solved in a better way, probably in the way that the promotional poster shows but hey you can't get everything.

If there is one show that this show will inevitably be compared to is Baccano.Is this show better than Baccano?Not really.But it isn't bad.


In terms of animation this show is not the best in the world. For the majority of the show, the animation is rather average and there are even times when they cut costs by focusing on frames where things are still and the character is not seen talking or doing anything else. But this does pay off because when things get real.. the animation shoots up so much in quality.The most prominent example being the first episode where the murder of Avillo's family takes place..really intense.The art style of the show is more colorful than Baccano to me.But this is not an understatement.The colors still look more drab and bland and depressing,because America at the time was drab and bland and depressing.There are many parts of America that gets put into detail from the buildings to the people.There are many differentiate facial expressions and hair cuts for the people(one guy has three different hair colors) and the eyebrows were very interesting.


With the sound,this show is still inferior to Baccano but it's not bad.The opening is impactful and moving with orchestral strings and sorrowful guitars. This fits into the vengeance part of the show but this part is not as apparent.The ending is very fitting but it is very forgetful.It is one of those slow songs that could put me to sleep.The soundtrack does a good job of fitting to the setting of the show to a T. But then again I wouldn't want to listen to it in my spare time.Unlike Baccano, this show doesn't have a crazy jazz theme and the soundtrack is more scary and intense than actually action packed.One theme called"the days" sounds like it belongs in a horror movie.If there is one thing in the show that lives up to Baccano, it's the dub.The actors did a really good job giving the characters different accents from Italian to Boston and even Canadian and Southern accents.


Onto the characters...


Avillo is a very apathetic person,I don't really feel close to him because he doesn't express that much emotion,at least in front of people he meets. For a majority of the show, he is very emotionless, but at other times he comes off as insane and when he goes through tough times he shows a huge bit of emotion.His real name is Angelo btw. I don't really think this is very important to contributing to the plot .Nero Vanetti is probably my favorite character because of how chill he is. When problems occur, he finds solutions for them in a effective way.When really bad things happen, you can tell that he doesn't really deserve it because he is such a nice guy defending his family name.I feel really sorry for Avillo's friend, Corteo.He is the guy who makes the moonshine that everyone is DYING for.He gets dragged into the whole shindig in the latter half and he really doesn't deserve it.There are also other people I kinda don't care about featuring a guy with glasses, Nero's younger brother and some other guys.The other character worth mentioning is that crazy guy with the most nonsensical haircut, Fango.He is crazy. He gets caught on fire but somehow survives and his haircut has three different colors in it.He is pretty cool,too.


In the end,I was satisfied with the show,but I expected more.This concept of prohibition is a very clever way to implement this revenge story,but sadly the family gang aspect really foreshadowed the revenge element.There are some great times and the last two episodes are pure chaos.In the historical drama aspect, it achieves but it doesn't excel.This doesn't mean you shouldn't watch it though.

Overall-7

I want a can of peaches now.

First things first, 91 Days is pretty amazing. It's basically a mafia version of Game of Thrones in anime format.
Story:
The show tells a mature and dark mafia story about revenge and boy does it tell it good. We have this quite common revenge plot from the Hollywood movies where the main character goes into the path of revenge because of the murder of his loved ones. 
The interesting aspect comes from its story telling; it is cunning, subtle and everything has a meaning from the conversations to the actions and subtle details that this shows has to offer. Nothing is meaningless. 
It is done welldrama when the characters' relationships will make you want to end up crying in the corner.


Animation and the quality:

There really isn't much to say about the animation department. The close up scenes look amazing, and while there is noticeable quality drop towards the end during three episodes (probably because of the budgeting) it could easily be forgiven for the story's sake. The scenes' importance shows in the animation when it matters even in low budget, so even in those three low budget episodes, when something matters and is really important the quality skyrockets once again.


Sub and Dub version:

Both sub and dub are great but there is a slight difference in characters' personality when comparing the versions. In Japanese version there is blank main character, goofy sidekick, and crazy villain but in English version every character seems more stable and mature, but somehow the relationship aspect's been left a little bit blank.


Notice:

This show might be best to watch more than once. First time ends up trying to figure out character relations and what impact they have with the story. 


For drama lovers:

If you're here to watch some exciting action anime that explains you all the time what is happening, this isn't the kind of show for you. But if you're up to some smart story telling and having an emotional rollercoaster this is kind of show to you. This show will rip your heart out from your chest, crushes it violently to the ground, picks it up and gives it a kiss before putting it back to your chest.


Truly a magnificent show and amazing ride. I recommend this wholeheartedly to everyone who wants to see exciting drama about revenge and bonds.

Ok, this is my first review I've ever made and never thought it would be for this genre, but I needed to. (Also forgive any mistakes since I'm not a native english speaker. Thanks~)
Story ~ 9
Mafia themed anime is not rare to find, but still 91 Days outstands. Seems a bit cliché the story of a person who search revenge for someone he loved and that's what 91 Days revolves around but, be patient and watch it to the end. It. Worths. It. 
The plot got darker (althought, it's refreshing to see a little humor time to time between dense parts) and it's a lotmore exciting while you reach the last episodes. Is a war between families to gain power through whiskey in the middle of the Prohibition. Everyone is betrayed by everyone, and betraying means death. 


Art ~ 6


I feel sorry the studio didn't put more effort on it. In some scenes is notably the lack of detail and fluidity (if you know what I mean). Although I like the character's designs and sceneries and hopefully the action scenes, I believe, were well made at least. Also the colors gave the appropiate mood to the story.


Sound ~ 8


As I mentioned with the colors, the BGM fitted good. I loved the OP made by TK from Ling Tosite Sigure, idk, it felt like it was Angelo itself who was singing. The ED also bring a nostalgic mood and space to somehow digest what just happened in the episode.


Character ~ 6


Although nearly every character had his own, very defined personality, there were little to nothing character development. Their personalities were mainly static in the whole story, however this wasn't a big problem regarding the situations exposed.

I must highlight some extreme behavior changes like for example with Corteo, but still think this is more like a plotwist than a character development. 


Enjoyment ~ 9


91 Days is really really enjoyable! The main purpose of an animation production (and others) is to: entertain. Entertainment doesn't mean to be funny at all. It's meant to produce experiences to the viewer, and 91 Days sure it does. The story is really exciting, thrilling and heartbreaking. Yup, the last episodes made me meditate of how these characters felt, how will you do if you were in a situation like this? The loss of a friend, of a member of your family, the fear of losing your own life... and the pain behind this. You really feel an empathy with the characters no matter who's side you are.


Greed, betrayal, forgiveness.... redemption?  Was it all in vain?

(91 days is a typical revenge story)
Story: 8
The story was told in way that will attract you, each episode will end with cliffhanger. Story was a bit predictable specially at the end. Pacing of the anime was perfect, each episode was full of drama and action. The drama and the suspense was the best part in the anime (hated the funny parts it was out of context). The ending was cliché (meh...)
Art: 6 
The style was realistic to fit the story. It was standard art nothing flashy. The character design was ok overall, the only one who was very good is Angleo. The design andthe colors of the cars was all the same.


Sound: 7

The voice acting for the characters was fitting for the story, specially one of the most complex character on the anime ( Fango). The background music was jazzy, not my style I didn’t like it. The opening, ending songs was ok not memorable.


Character: 8 

The character development was very good, each character got his own strength and flaws to overcome. after some episodes, you will see Angleo grow form a boy to a Mafia man. The best characters I thought was amazing Angleo and Fango, each got a story to tell, the only one I dislike was corteo, crybaby all the time. 


Enjoyment: 9 

Guys don’t miss this show its very good and you will enjoy it, maybe not if you are not the type to like mafia story’s. I will not forget this show one of the best specially the characters. If you didn’t watch it yet please go and give it a chance. 


Overall: 8

Don't watch this if you want a satisfying ending.
No I'm kidding. Do watch it just don't expect the ending to give you what you want. (maybe i'm just bitter.)
Also be aware this gets started really slow. However if your a fan of mob movies you'll be used to that kind of thing and probably like this. Actually I think this would be a good anime to show some one your just introducing to the world of anime because it really doesn't have an anime feel to itl It's an animated mob TV series completely with conspiracy, betrayal, prohibition era politics, and of course gun fights.I found the story to be slow and kind of lacking but then I usually feel that way about mafia inspired movies/series so again if you like that genre of western film you'll actually probably like this. I definitely think it was at least worth watching and it was a nice change from the sometimes zany and convoluted world of anime. You should definitely give it a try but be prepared to watch at least through episode 5 before giving up.\n
The only other things I've seen that I'd say somewhat compare to this are maybe darker than black (one of my faves) and phantom: requiem for the phantom (an anime i hated.) So take whatever you can from that lol.

This anime was and wasn’t what I expected. After the first episode I did expect a kind of revenge plot to take form and because it was dealing with mafias I also expected people to double cross each other and whatnot. I wasn’t terribly disappointed in how this anime turned out but I also didn’t think it was anything special. 
If you are looking for a show that has some more adult themes and a pretty decent array of characters this is a pretty good show. It’s not one I would say was amazing though. I would categorize it as pretty average. The show didn’tdo anything especially good or bad. The story was kind of interesting, the setting was different, but nothing in particular really stuck out to me.

Story: So the plot and setup of the plot is rather self-explanatory: protagonist lost family to mafia, manages to get away, and plots revenge once the resources became available. There are a few reasons I wasn't fond of the plot, but the main one was rather personal. I think revenge is foolish and impulsive; it requires a lot of effort and you get little to no reward out of it. The main reason I continued was to see if the main protagonist would realize this and change his mind. (SPOILERS AHEAD) and he kinda sorta did in a way. He technically got his revenge, butdidn't even nail the target he specifically went there to get. I felt like he targeted many people vaguely involved or nailed people majorly involved but were dying anyway. He put his only family left through hell and murdered him for the cause, BUT got weak-kneed when he finally earned Nero's trust. So, congrats, he changed his mind eventually, but could he had decided that BEFORE he pulled that s***? Like, what the hell do you think Corteo is thinking?! Some credit it to the dark mood of the anime, but there is a difference between dark and just tragically idiotic. It was like watching the end of Romeo and Juliet (if he just figured that s*** out beforehand, things would've been fine.)


Art: Don't have much to say about the art. I liked the design, the clothes, and the grunge look that matched the setting and plot.


Sound: I fell in love with LTS's Signal song. I also thought the sexy jazzy music of the sound track and ending were appropriate.


Character: If you read my regards on the plot, you probably know why I already didn't like Angelo. Looking back at it, there were no characters I was too attached to and felt like certain tropes or stereotypes were becoming constant: cocky ringleaders and bounty hunters, mafia grunts who aren't what they seem like at the surface, basic mafia grunts who ARE what you see and are just "following orders", 2nd hand men who feared losing respect and/or status. And the occasional irrelevant female character.


Enjoyment: It took me a while to write this review just because I couldn't remember important aspects and facts about the show. That in itself should tell you about my enjoyment (it was like a boring, forgettable chore for those who're up too late to use all their brain cells. No shame, no shade!! XD)
